Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
Dear Secretary of Education Miguel Cardona,

I support the Department of Education (“Department”) taking action to protect the rights of transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students to play school sports.  

I also urge the Department to strengthen its Title IX rule so that transgender, nonbinary, and intersex youth can access the full benefits of an education, including by playing school sports as they are. Defending this right is crucial for these students’ well-being and ability to learn without discrimination. 

Transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students experience high rates of sex discrimination and harassment at school, which is linked to poor academic and health outcomes. Affirming policies that allow students to play sports consistent with their gender can reduce stigma, depression, and isolation, and contribute to positive academic outcomes like fewer absences, better grades, and higher chances of completing high school.   

Transgender, nonbinary, and intersex youth need and deserve an opportunity to play school sports alongside their peers. This is especially the case in contexts that are primarily about the social, educational, and physical benefits of sport, rather than elite competition.  

Therefore, the Department should make clear that restrictions on transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students’ ability to play sports are never permitted at the K-12 or club college level. 

Transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students have been playing sports with their peers for years and with zero problems! In fact, barring trans women and girls from playing with other women and girls harms all women and girls because it can allow anyone to accuse any student athlete of not “really” being a woman or a girl.  Many times, this leads to “sex testing,” which includes horrific and invasive practices like genital inspections or hormonal tests for students to “prove” their gender. 
 
The Department should explicitly state that requiring sex testing of student athletes violates Title IX because such testing causes significant harm to affected students and is never necessary to advance an important educational objective. Sex testing invades students' privacy, is often enforced arbitrarily based on prejudice, and sends deeply stigmatizing and damaging messages to all youth that are completely inconsistent with a supportive educational environment. 
 
Discriminating against and demonizing some students because of who they are or how they look directly violates Title IX. I urge the Department to finalize and strengthen the Department’s Title IX rule to provide strong, clear protections for transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students to participate fully in sports consistent with their gender identity.

Sincerely,
Carla Behrens
Longmont, CO 80503

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
Dear Secretary Cardona,

I write to oppose the proposed Title IX rule that would completely reverse the current protections for women and girls in sports. 

This rule’s interpretation of Title IX would prohibit schools from establishing policies for sports based on biological sex. Instead, it would create uncomfortable, even dangerous, situations for student athletes, and would put teachers, staff, and coaches who care about students and the reality of biological sex in the untenable position of violating their beliefs.

The proposal, if adopted, would protect only a claimed “transgender” status, which will allow boys and men to compete on teams once reserved for girls and women. This is a blatant attempt to undermine 50 years of Title IX protections for female athletes, as well as the many states and localities that have passed legislation to protect women’s and girls’ sports. The federal government should not pressure local schools and school districts to ignore biology, safety, and fairness. 

The proposed rule would unreasonably prohibit boys-only and girls-only sports teams in elementary schools. I do not believe that the Department of Education is acting in good faith when it claims it will consider the needs of middle, high school, or college aged women and girls by requiring them to make their case and convince you to allow them to retain their sex-based rights under a reimagined Title IX. Women should not have to petition the government to in order to keep their basic rights to safety and fairness. 

The abolition of male and female categories will allow males to access private spaces previously reserved for women and girls. Coaches will be forced to supervise opposite sex young athletes in locker rooms, while girls and women will be forced to share showers, changing areas, and possibly beds or bedrooms (when traveling for games) with boys and men based on “gender identity” claims. Physical differences between boys and girls will put girls at higher risk of injury on the playing field.  Just recently, news broke of a female high school volleyball player who suffered long-term injuries last fall when she was spiked in the face by a male player on the opposing team. This young man was allowed to join the girl’s team because he identifies as a transgender female. 

Boys and girls, men and women currently have the chance to play on the teams aligned with their biological sex. Protecting women’s and girls’ sports doesn’t “ban” anyone from participating, it simply ensures that women’s sports can recognize biological reality rather than being bullied by individuals with a subjective (and often transitory) sense of “gender identity.” I oppose these changes to Title IX and object to the Biden Administration bullying schools and states by holding federal funds hostage to their transgender agenda.

I ask that you protect the integrity of women’s athletics and Title IX by withdrawing this proposed rule. 

Thank you.

Sincerely,
Mr. Paul Bransfield

Protecting women’s and girls’ sports doesn’t “ban” anyone from participating, it simply ensures that women’s sports can recognize biological reality rather than being bullied by individuals with a subjective (and often transitory) sense of “gender identity.” I oppose these changes to Title IX and object to the Biden Administration bullying schools and states by holding federal funds hostage to their transgender agenda.

I ask that you protect the integrity of women’s athletics and Title IX by withdrawing this proposed rule. 

Thank you.

Sincerely,
Kirk Weiss

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
I strongly oppose the Department of Education’s proposed rule that threatens to withhold funding for children’s education in exchange for accepting someone else’s “adopted” sexual identity.

The biology between male and female is undeniably inherent and distinct to each sex, giving males, specifically, physical characteristics that make them naturally dominant over females in most sports.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
Dear Secretary Cardona,

I write to oppose the proposed Title IX rule that would completely reverse the current protections for women and girls in sports. 

This rule’s interpretation of Title IX would prohibit schools from establishing policies for sports based on biological sex. Instead, it would create uncomfortable, even dangerous, situations for student athletes, and would put teachers, staff, and coaches who care about students and the reality of biological sex in the untenable position of violating their beliefs.

The proposal, if adopted, would protect only a claimed “transgender” status, which will allow boys and men to compete on teams once reserved for girls and women. This is a blatant attempt to undermine 50 years of Title IX protections for female athletes, as well as the many states and localities that have passed legislation to protect women’s and girls’ sports. The federal government should not pressure local schools and school districts to ignore biology, safety, and fairness. 

The proposed rule would unreasonably prohibit boys-only and girls-only sports teams in elementary schools. I do not believe that the Department of Education is acting in good faith when it claims it will consider the needs of middle, high school, or college aged women and girls by requiring them to make their case and convince you to allow them to retain their sex-based rights under a reimagined Title IX. Women should not have to petition the government to in order to keep their basic rights to safety and fairness. 

The abolition of male and female categories will allow males to access private spaces previously reserved for women and girls. Coaches will be forced to supervise opposite sex young athletes in locker rooms, while girls and women will be forced to share showers, changing areas, and possibly beds or bedrooms (when traveling for games) with boys and men based on “gender identity” claims. Physical differences between boys and girls will put girls at higher risk of injury on the playing field.  Just recently, news broke of a female high school volleyball player who suffered long-term injuries last fall when she was spiked in the face by a male player on the opposing team. This young man was allowed to join the girl’s team because he identifies as a transgender female. 

Boys and girls, men and women currently have the chance to play on the teams aligned with their biological sex. Protecting women’s and girls’ sports doesn’t “ban” anyone from participating, it simply ensures that women’s sports can recognize biological reality rather than being bullied by individuals with a subjective (and often transitory) sense of “gender identity.” I oppose these changes to Title IX and object to the Biden Administration bullying schools and states by holding federal funds hostage to their transgender agenda.

I ask that you protect the integrity of women’s athletics and Title IX by withdrawing this proposed rule. 

Thank you.

Sincerely,
Mr. Bob Kyle

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
My name is **Jacqui Herter**. Im writing in regard to the Department of Educations Proposed Rule  Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Sex in Education Programs or Activities Receiving Federal Financial Assistance: Sex-Related Eligibility Criteria for Male and Female Athletic Teams (RIN:1870-AA19).

I am a trans woman. I struggled with my issues and being accepted for decades. At 50 I realized and accepted who I am and what described me. I came to a point where my choices were transition or suicide. Nearly 10 years later I am the most well adjusted I have ever been. I have accepted me and discovered, no one else can accept you till you do so yourself. It doesn't mean every one will but not one can till you have made that step.

I also had children with a number of friends who are on the gender spectrum. Many suffered at their parents and peers interactions. If given the chance to build relationships from an early age and interact with team mates, acceptance becomes easier in general. It builds self esteem, and gives one the experience of being able to rely on others.

Transgender youth, just like all youth, simply want to participate in the same educational activities as their peers, including athletics. All transgender students  at every age and in every sport  should be presumed eligible to participate in sports consistent with their gender identity. And schools should not limit a students participation on a team solely because they are transgender.

Jacqueline Herter

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
I am writing to address concerns that my family and I have regarding the newly proposed rule, “Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Sex in Education Programs or Activities Receiving Federal Financial Assistance: Sex-Related Eligibility Criteria for Male and Female Athletic Teams” (RIN  1870-AA19; Docket ID ED-2022-OCR-0143; “Proposed Rule”). This Proposed Rule undercuts states that are protecting female athletes from ongoing discrimination and leaves women without protection when male students are allowed to join their teams. In fact, the majority of states have introduced legislation to protect female athletes, and so far twenty of them have passed those protections into law. This is not a minority viewpoint: it's common sense.

Women deserve a fair shot in sports, but when males are allowed to compete in female sports contests, that fair shot disappears. Males have an undeniable biological advantage over female athletes no matter the amount of testosterone suppression is taken–but the administration will allow males to compete with females anyway if this rule is finalized. When this happens, girls and women lose out on championships, scholarships, and other opportunities meant just for them.
 
The Proposed Rule states that if schools apply “a one-size-fits-all approach, they rely on overbroad generalizations that do not account for the nature of particular sports, the level of competition at issue, and the grade or education level of students to which they apply.” Those schools using that a standard across the board would thus not be in compliance with the rule as proposed. This leaves the door open to dramatically confuse schools and states on what qualifies as legitimate reasons, such as physical harm, to keep women’s sports for biological women only.
 
I am calling on the Biden Administration to not put ideology and politics over girls and women. Please rescind this rule and make it clear for schools that women’s sports is for biological women only, as Title IX originally intended.
 
Thank you for considering this request.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
Dear Secretary of Education Miguel Cardona,

I support the Department of Education (“Department”) taking action to protect the rights of transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students to play school sports.  

I also urge the Department to strengthen its Title IX rule so that transgender, nonbinary, and intersex youth can access the full benefits of an education, including by playing school sports as they are. Defending this right is crucial for these students’ well-being and ability to learn without discrimination. 

Transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students experience high rates of sex discrimination and harassment at school, which is linked to poor academic and health outcomes. Affirming policies that allow students to play sports consistent with their gender can reduce stigma, depression, and isolation, and contribute to positive academic outcomes like fewer absences, better grades, and higher chances of completing high school.   

Transgender, nonbinary, and intersex youth need and deserve an opportunity to play school sports alongside their peers. This is especially the case in contexts that are primarily about the social, educational, and physical benefits of sport, rather than elite competition.  

Therefore, the Department should make clear that restrictions on transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students’ ability to play sports are never permitted at the K-12 or club college level. 

Transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students have been playing sports with their peers for years and with zero problems! In fact, barring trans women and girls from playing with other women and girls harms all women and girls because it can allow anyone to accuse any student athlete of not “really” being a woman or a girl.  Many times, this leads to “sex testing,” which includes horrific and invasive practices like genital inspections or hormonal tests for students to “prove” their gender. 
 
The Department should explicitly state that requiring sex testing of student athletes violates Title IX because such testing causes significant harm to affected students and is never necessary to advance an important educational objective. Sex testing invades students' privacy, is often enforced arbitrarily based on prejudice, and sends deeply stigmatizing and damaging messages to all youth that are completely inconsistent with a supportive educational environment. 
 
Discriminating against and demonizing some students because of who they are or how they look directly violates Title IX. I urge the Department to finalize and strengthen the Department’s Title IX rule to provide strong, clear protections for transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students to participate fully in sports consistent with their gender identity.

Sincerely,
sandra nelson
Okmulgee, OK 74447

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
I am writing to elevate the American Psychological Association (APA) Services’ comments on this proposed rule. Specifically, I am urging the Department to please:

-	Move forward with its proposal to clarify school districts’ obligations to ensure safe, supportive, and non-discriminatory environments.
-	Move forward with its proposal to ensure that state laws categorically banning transgender, non-binary, and intersex students from participating in sports consistent with their gender identity are unlawful. 
-	Continue to rely on psychological science, research and data when developing education and civil rights policy. For example, please consider a 2020 policy statement adopted by APA and the National Association of School Psychologists recommending safer environments for gender diverse, transgender, and intersex students.
-	Clarify the exact criteria schools must use to determine which, if any, cases allow for the restriction of transgender, non-binary, and intersex student participation on sports teams consistent with their gender identity. This must include additional examples of the types of restrictions that would not meet the rule’s standards for exclusion.

This NPRM comes at a particularly troubling time for our nation’s LGBTQ+ students. Nationally representative CDC Youth Risk Behavioral Survey (YRBS) data show that lesbian, gay and bisexual youth are substantially more likely to have experienced all forms of violence and worse mental health outcomes than their heterosexual peers. In 2022 nearly 82% of LGBTQ+ students ages 13-21 reported feeling unsafe while at school last year, and 68% said they felt unsafe specifically because of their sexual orientation and gender identity or expression. In the same survey, LGBTQ+ students reported experiencing discriminatory policies or practices at school, with 11% reporting that school staff or coaches had prevented or discouraged them from playing sports because they identified as LGBTQ+.

As such, I am grateful for the opportunity to comment on this important and timely proposal.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
I call on the U.S. Department of Education to stop undermining the protections of Title IX for
female student athletes by coercing schools to allow men and boys to compete in womens and
girls athletics.

Forcing female athletes to compete in their chosen sports against men and boys who identify as
female will destroy a half century of progress under Title IX for women and girls. You will rob
females of spots on teams, push them off podiums to make room for males who have undeniable
biological advantages over female competitors, and deter them from competing in the first place.
This proposed rule will also cause physical harm to female athletes when they have to compete
against larger, stronger men.

The Departments proposed regulation defies Title IX, whose purpose is to provide equal
educational opportunities, including in athletics, based on sex, not gender identity. This
proposed rule denies women and girls an equal playing field in school athletics and sets the
clock back over 50 years, to the time before Congress passed Title IX.

I urge the Department to obey the law and follow common sense by withdrawing its plan to force
women and girls to compete against men and boys in the athletic arena.

Let transgenders compete against transgenders! We are talking about the world of sports which is a physical reality. So let’s use the physical, biological traits to determine IN FAIRNESS that whoever competes, competes against the SAME physical, biological traits. Sports is a PHYSICAL competition. 

Do not implement this rule—it will hurt America’s daughters.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
I am writing in opposition to this rule. It puts women on defense, forcing them to justify a right to their own sports and their own spaces.

Allowing males, no matter how they self-identify, into women’s sports erases all pretense of fairness. This rule is blatantly sexist and unfair.

This rule destroys fairness, erases women’s spaces, and eliminates opportunities for women. Protection for women’s sports were created to elevate women to a level playing field, and increase opportunities for scholarships, education, and entrance into the workforce. This rule undoes the work that came before it.

Furthermore, this rule creates a false pretense that women’s physical safety is important to the Department of Education. But any right to safety that must be justified on a case by case basis is not a right. This new rule jeopardizes women by forcing schools to try and win a bureaucratic paperfight to protect women’s sports for women. 

Instead of focusing on their studies, homework, and sports practices, this rule puts the burden on young female athletes to spend their time advocating to their school administration and justifying to the Department of Education that their safety matters.
As a father of four daughters. I have coached them in softball and soccer. The male body is stronger with more body mass and gives and unfair advantage over female athlete. Do not implement this rule- it will hurt America’s daughters.
Sincerely, Sincerely Lewis Groberg

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
I am writing in opposition to this rule. It puts women on defense, forcing them to justify a right to their own sports and their own spaces.

Allowing males, no matter how they self-identify, into women’s sports erases all pretense of fairness. This rule is blatantly sexist and unfair.

This rule destroys fairness, erases women’s spaces, and eliminates opportunities for women. Protection for women’s sports were created to elevate women to a level playing field, and increase opportunities for scholarships, education, and entrance into the workforce. This rule undoes the work that came before it.

Furthermore, this rule creates a false pretense that women’s physical safety is important to the Department of Education. But any right to safety that must be justified on a case by case basis is not a right. This new rule jeopardizes women by forcing schools to try and win a bureaucratic paperfight to protect women’s sports for women. 

Instead of focusing on their studies, homework, and sports practices, this rule puts the burden on young female athletes to spend their time advocating to their school administration and justifying to the Department of Education that their safety matters.


Do not implement this rule—it will hurt America’s daughters.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
Dear Secretary of Education Miguel Cardona,

I support the Department of Education (“Department”) taking action to protect the rights of transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students to play school sports.  

I also urge the Department to strengthen its Title IX rule so that transgender, nonbinary, and intersex youth can access the full benefits of an education, including by playing school sports as they are. Defending this right is crucial for these students’ well-being and ability to learn without discrimination. 

Transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students experience high rates of sex discrimination and harassment at school, which is linked to poor academic and health outcomes. Affirming policies that allow students to play sports consistent with their gender can reduce stigma, depression, and isolation, and contribute to positive academic outcomes like fewer absences, better grades, and higher chances of completing high school.   

Transgender, nonbinary, and intersex youth need and deserve an opportunity to play school sports alongside their peers. This is especially the case in contexts that are primarily about the social, educational, and physical benefits of sport, rather than elite competition.  

Therefore, the Department should make clear that restrictions on transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students’ ability to play sports are never permitted at the K-12 or club college level. 

Transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students have been playing sports with their peers for years and with zero problems! In fact, barring trans women and girls from playing with other women and girls harms all women and girls because it can allow anyone to accuse any student athlete of not “really” being a woman or a girl.  Many times, this leads to “sex testing,” which includes horrific and invasive practices like genital inspections or hormonal tests for students to “prove” their gender. 
 
The Department should explicitly state that requiring sex testing of student athletes violates Title IX because such testing causes significant harm to affected students and is never necessary to advance an important educational objective. Sex testing invades students' privacy, is often enforced arbitrarily based on prejudice, and sends deeply stigmatizing and damaging messages to all youth that are completely inconsistent with a supportive educational environment. 
 
Discriminating against and demonizing some students because of who they are or how they look directly violates Title IX. I urge the Department to finalize and strengthen the Department’s Title IX rule to provide strong, clear protections for transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students to participate fully in sports consistent with their gender identity.

Sincerely,
Aumna Iqbal
Jersey City, NJ 07306

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
Only someone with a very dark agenda would penalize women in their sports by letting men compete against them when men already have a sports organization..

I strongly oppose the Department of Education’s proposed rule that threatens to withhold funding for children’s education in exchange for accepting someone else’s “adopted” sexual identity.

The biology between male and female is undeniably inherent and distinct to each sex, giving males, specifically, physical characteristics that make them naturally dominant over females in most sports.

The department’s proposal creates an unfair advantage to males and undermines girls’ and women’s sports.

I urge the Department of Education to recognize the differences and stop placating the movement to destroy the true equality that women have worked so hard to achieve.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment: I am an 80 year old woman who loves sports!  Title IX has allowed females to participate in all sports and I applaud it.  However, no one dreamed it would allow biological males to compete in women's sports.  To allow this destroys what made Title IX so important to women of my era....the possibility of competition at the highest level starting at an early age.  Reject the changes to Title IX.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
I call on the U.S. Department of Education to stop undermining the protections of Title IX for
female student athletes by coercing schools to allow men and boys to compete in womens and
girls athletics.

Forcing female athletes to compete in their chosen sports against men and boys who identify as
female will destroy a half century of progress under Title IX for women and girls. You will rob
females of spots on teams, push them off podiums to make room for males who have undeniable
biological advantages over female competitors, and deter them from competing in the first place.
This proposed rule will also cause physical harm to female athletes when they have to compete
against larger, stronger men.

The Departments proposed regulation defies Title IX, whose purpose is to provide equal
educational opportunities, including in athletics, based on sex, not gender identity. This
proposed rule denies women and girls an equal playing field in school athletics and sets the
clock back over 50 years, to the time before Congress passed Title IX.

I urge the Department to obey the law and follow common sense by withdrawing its plan to force
women and girls to compete against men and boys in the athletic arena.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
This new rule (which proposes a more inclusive approach to athletics) allows students to play on teams based on their gender identity, not their biology. It also requires schools receiving federal fundswhich includes schools in all states and at all levelsto provide access to locker rooms and other spaces consistent with a students gender identity.

The problem is that this rule (if implemented) could lead to biological males competing against young girls in sports. Given the size, bone density, and muscle mass differentials between the biological sexes, this creates a significant (and unfair) advantage for biological males who have transitioned. So while the Biden administration is trying to promote fairness, it will likely have the opposite effect.

Additionally, allowing biological males into female sports leagues could make it impossible for female athletes to find success, as those athletes would be competing against people who have superior physical strength due to higher levels of testosterone.
This isn't just unfair; it's also dangerous. If a biological male were allowed into a female locker room, young women could be put at risk of assault or harassment. 

This proposed rule change and the corresponding push for gender inclusion in sports might be well-intentioned but it certainly misguided. As a result, the Biden Administration should not move forward with this new rule! For pushing progressive ideas, this just brings females back into the dark ages. Not progressive at all.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
I am writing to voice my deep concern over the Biden Administration's proposed changes. These changes will coerce schools into allowing biological males to play in young girls' sports and use their locker rooms. 

Allowing biological males into young girls sports puts female athletes at a scientifically proven physical disadvantage. Given recent history we can expect to see biologically female athletes struggle to compete with their biologically male competitors. It also exposes young girls to potential sexual misconduct or predatory behavior from male students or other adults with access to locker rooms or similar areas at school. This doesn't just violate the spirit of fairness, it also puts our daughters in danger.

While inclusion is an important value, we must also recognize that inclusion should never come at the expense of safety or fairness. 

Therefore, I urge you to take action now to protect our daughters' safety and uphold the integrity of sports competition

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
The Department of Educations  proposed rule attempts to intimidate school districts into allowing biological males who identify as female to participate in womens sports. This would mean that the male athletes have access to locker rooms and other facilities that were made specifically for female athletes. Not only does this go against the spirit of fairness, but it also puts our daughters at risk of harm and abuse. 


By letting biological males compete with girls in sports, the Biden Administration is erasing any trace of fairness or safety for female athletes. It sets a precedent for young girls that their hard work and dedication are not enough, since they will be competing against someone who has a physiological advantage over them. Furthermore, it puts these young girls in a compromising position by allowing biological males to use the same locker rooms as them. This opens up the possibility of sexual assault and other forms of harassment or abuse from people who do not share the same biological sex. 


This policy directly contradicts the very purpose of Title IX, which was passed in 1972 to promote equal opportunities for men and women in education, including athletics. Allowing biological males to compete with females goes against one of its primary goalsthat men and women should have equal access to sporting activities without discrimination based on sex. If enacted this policy sets a dangerous precedent that will undermine Title IXs original intent and put womens rights at risk. 


The Education Departments  proposed policy is dangerous and wrong on many levels. It undermines fairness by giving male-bodied athletes an advantage over their female-bodied counterparts, compromises safety by allowing male-bodied athletes access to female locker rooms, and violates Title IX by promoting discrimination based on gender identity rather than sex. This policy puts our daughters at risk.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
The Biden Administrations proposed rule attempts to intimidate schools into letting student athletes play on sports teams that fit their gender identity. This inclusion put students in danger by allowing biological males to not only play on young girls' sports teams, but also use their locker rooms. This does not just violate the principle of fairness; it puts our daughters in danger. 

Unfortunately, this proposed policy completely disregards biology and ignores the fact that male bodies are naturally bigger and stronger than female bodies - which creates an unfair advantage when they compete in athletics. This means that male-bodied students could easily dominate female-bodied ones on a sports team and thus rob women of potential scholarships or awards - along with making it harder for them to get accepted into college or other athletic programs down the road.  

Furthermore, this policy puts our daughters in danger by allowing biological males access to their locker rooms. Not only does this violate privacy concerns but it can also put girls at risk of physical harm if a male-bodied student were to enter a locker room and harass or assault them while they were changing clothes or showering. There have already been instances where this has happened and until we can ensure that all locker rooms are safe from potential predators, these policies should not be implemented.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
Dear Secretary Cardona,

I write to oppose the proposed Title IX rule that would completely reverse the current protections for women and girls in sports. 

This rule’s interpretation of Title IX would prohibit schools from establishing policies for sports based on biological sex. Instead, it would create uncomfortable, even dangerous, situations for student athletes, and would put teachers, staff, and coaches who care about students and the reality of biological sex in the untenable position of violating their beliefs.

The proposal, if adopted, would protect only a claimed “transgender” status, which will allow boys and men to compete on teams once reserved for girls and women. This is a blatant attempt to undermine 50 years of Title IX protections for female athletes, as well as the many states and localities that have passed legislation to protect women’s and girls’ sports. The federal government should not pressure local schools and school districts to ignore biology, safety, and fairness. 

The proposed rule would unreasonably prohibit boys-only and girls-only sports teams in elementary schools. I do not believe that the Department of Education is acting in good faith when it claims it will consider the needs of middle, high school, or college aged women and girls by requiring them to make their case and convince you to allow them to retain their sex-based rights under a reimagined Title IX. Women should not have to petition the government to in order to keep their basic rights to safety and fairness. 

The abolition of male and female categories will allow males to access private spaces previously reserved for women and girls. Coaches will be forced to supervise opposite sex young athletes in locker rooms, while girls and women will be forced to share showers, changing areas, and possibly beds or bedrooms (when traveling for games) with boys and men based on “gender identity” claims. Physical differences between boys and girls will put girls at higher risk of injury on the playing field.  Just recently, news broke of a female high school volleyball player who suffered long-term injuries last fall when she was spiked in the face by a male player on the opposing team. This young man was allowed to join the girl’s team because he identifies as a transgender female. 

Boys and girls, men and women currently have the chance to play on the teams aligned with their biological sex. Protecting women’s and girls’ sports doesn’t “ban” anyone from participating, it simply ensures that women’s sports can recognize biological reality rather than being bullied by individuals with a subjective (and often transitory) sense of “gender identity.” I oppose these changes to Title IX and object to the Biden Administration bullying schools and states by holding federal funds hostage to their transgender agenda.

I ask that you protect the integrity of women’s athletics and Title IX by withdrawing this proposed rule. 

Thank you.

Sincerely,
Nancy Bouwman

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
Dear Secretary of Education Miguel Cardona,

I support the Department of Education (“Department”) taking action to protect the rights of transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students to play school sports.  

I also urge the Department to strengthen its Title IX rule so that transgender, nonbinary, and intersex youth can access the full benefits of an education, including by playing school sports as they are. Defending this right is crucial for these students’ well-being and ability to learn without discrimination. 

Transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students experience high rates of sex discrimination and harassment at school, which is linked to poor academic and health outcomes. Affirming policies that allow students to play sports consistent with their gender can reduce stigma, depression, and isolation, and contribute to positive academic outcomes like fewer absences, better grades, and higher chances of completing high school.   

Transgender, nonbinary, and intersex youth need and deserve an opportunity to play school sports alongside their peers. This is especially the case in contexts that are primarily about the social, educational, and physical benefits of sport, rather than elite competition.  

Therefore, the Department should make clear that restrictions on transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students’ ability to play sports are never permitted at the K-12 or club college level. 

Transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students have been playing sports with their peers for years and with zero problems! In fact, barring trans women and girls from playing with other women and girls harms all women and girls because it can allow anyone to accuse any student athlete of not “really” being a woman or a girl.  Many times, this leads to “sex testing,” which includes horrific and invasive practices like genital inspections or hormonal tests for students to “prove” their gender. 
 
The Department should explicitly state that requiring sex testing of student athletes violates Title IX because such testing causes significant harm to affected students and is never necessary to advance an important educational objective. Sex testing invades students' privacy, is often enforced arbitrarily based on prejudice, and sends deeply stigmatizing and damaging messages to all youth that are completely inconsistent with a supportive educational environment. 
 
Discriminating against and demonizing some students because of who they are or how they look directly violates Title IX. I urge the Department to finalize and strengthen the Department’s Title IX rule to provide strong, clear protections for transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students to participate fully in sports consistent with their gender identity.

Sincerely,
Michael Shores
Tempe, AZ 85281

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
I am writing this letter to express concerns regarding the proposed policies introduced by the Department of Education. These policies are attempting to pressure schools into allowing student athletes to play in sports of the opposite biological sex. This poses a significant risk to the safety of young athletes and undermines fairness in sports competitions.

Districts are being coerced to adopt 'inclusive policies so that they can continue to receive federal funding. However,this policy presents significant risks to students' safety. Allowing biological males to play in young girls' sports and use their locker rooms poses a threat to female students' privacy and safety. Furthermore, it undermines the integrity of sports competition and is against the spirit of equality of opportunity in sports.

This policy is unacceptable, and it is important that the federal government protects our students' safety in sports activities. It is crucial that the government ensures that schools prioritize the safety and well-being of all students, regardless of their gender identity. While schools should be encouraged to promote an inclusive environment for all students, it must be a setting that doesn't put anyone at risk or promote unfair competition.

As a citizen, I urge you to consider these concerns and take appropriate actions to protect students' safety and uphold the integrity of sports competition.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
I am strongly opposed to this proposed rule change. Title IX was enacted to give women and girls access to athletics which they previously did not have. This proposed rule would allow biological males to dominate women's athletics do to the greater muscle mass and strength male bodies possess. The swimmer Lia Thomas is an excellent example. Not only would this rule take opportunities away from women and girls when positions on female athletic teams are filled by biological males and award podiums are occupied by biological males, there are also serious safety concerns in any sort of contact sport when biological male bodies collide with female bodies.

Im sure youre receiving a lot of comments about this topic, but I wanted to make sure you hear from me too. I don't believe that this is what our country stands for, and I hope you will reconsider your position on this issue. This is cruel and unfair to our girls, who deserve the opportunity to compete for scholarships and awards on a level playing field.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
I am writing to address concerns that my family and I have regarding the newly proposed rule, “Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Sex in Education Programs or Activities Receiving Federal Financial Assistance: Sex-Related Eligibility Criteria for Male and Female Athletic Teams” (RIN  1870-AA19; Docket ID ED-2022-OCR-0143; “Proposed Rule”). This Proposed Rule undercuts states that are protecting female athletes from ongoing discrimination and leaves women without protection when male students are allowed to join their teams. In fact, the majority of states have introduced legislation to protect female athletes, and so far twenty of them have passed those protections into law. This is not a minority viewpoint: it's common sense.

Women deserve a fair shot in sports, but when males are allowed to compete in female sports contests, that fair shot disappears. Males have an undeniable biological advantage over female athletes no matter the amount of testosterone suppression is taken–but the administration will allow males to compete with females anyway if this rule is finalized. When this happens, girls and women lose out on championships, scholarships, and other opportunities meant just for them.
 
The Proposed Rule states that if schools apply “a one-size-fits-all approach, they rely on overbroad generalizations that do not account for the nature of particular sports, the level of competition at issue, and the grade or education level of students to which they apply.” Those schools using that a standard across the board would thus not be in compliance with the rule as proposed. This leaves the door open to dramatically confuse schools and states on what qualifies as legitimate reasons, such as physical harm, to keep women’s sports for biological women only.
 
I am calling on the Biden Administration to not put ideology and politics over girls and women. Please rescind this rule and make it clear for schools that women’s sports is for biological women only, as Title IX originally intended.
 
Thank you for considering this request.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
If you have God given male parts, you are NOT a female
PERIOD

I strongly oppose the Department of Education’s proposed rule that threatens to withhold funding for children’s education in exchange for accepting someone else’s “adopted” sexual identity.

The biology between male and female is undeniably inherent and distinct to each sex, giving males, specifically, physical characteristics that make them naturally dominant over females in most sports.

The department’s proposal creates an unfair advantage to males and undermines girls’ and women’s sports.

I urge the Department of Education to recognize the differences and stop placating the movement to destroy the true equality that women have worked so hard to achieve.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
This proposed rule is unfair, raises safety concerns, and tramples on womens rights. 

The Biden Administrations proposed change to Title IX claims to promote equality by allowing students to participate in sports based on their gender identity, not their biological sex. While this may seem like a win for fairness and inclusion, it violates the spirit of fairness that underpins women's athletics. Allowing biological males to compete against biological females puts biologically male athletes at an unfair advantage and could have far-reaching consequences for women's rights in sports. 

This policy will not only violate the spirit of fairness but it could also put female students in danger. By allowing biological males access to female locker rooms, showers, and other facilities, our daughters are at greater risk of sexual assault or harassment. Schools should not be incentivized by federal tax dollars to allow policies that put our children in harm's way. This is unacceptable! 

It is important to note that this policy does not just threaten fairness or put our daughters at risk, it also tramples on womens rights in general. A policy that permits biological males to enter female spaces, sends girls a message that their bodies do not matter as much as those of male-identifying individuals, and that women are second-class citizens. This undermines decades of progress made towards gender equality and equal rights for both sexes.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment: As a former educator for all levels of students from preschool, elementary, high school, junior college and university professor, I adamantly oppose any person identified at birth as male, no matter whether transitioning or identifying as female, to be included on any female athletic team or program for female sports. It absolutely creates unfair competition and in reality discriminates against persons designated as female at birth with generally less strength, muscular build and bodily stamina for sports of any kind. Athletes who identified at birth as males may have higher testosterone levels than females identified at birth and likely will outperform most born as females. Sports to be fair and balanced, not giving a gender at birth boost to any person identified as a biological male at birth regardless of sex change or transgender status. Females from birth should only be compatible competing with others also from birth identified as female. Birth genes matter!

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
I am writing in opposition to this rule. It puts women on defense, forcing them to justify a right to their own sports and their own spaces.

Allowing males, no matter how they self-identify, into women’s sports erases all pretense of fairness. This rule is blatantly sexist and unfair.

This rule destroys fairness, erases women’s spaces, and eliminates opportunities for women. Protection for women’s sports were created to elevate women to a level playing field, and increase opportunities for scholarships, education, and entrance into the workforce. This rule undoes the work that came before it.

Furthermore, this rule creates a false pretense that women’s physical safety is important to the Department of Education. But any right to safety that must be justified on a case by case basis is not a right. This new rule jeopardizes women by forcing schools to try and win a bureaucratic paperfight to protect women’s sports for women. 

Instead of focusing on their studies, homework, and sports practices, this rule puts the burden on young female athletes to spend their time advocating to their school administration and justifying to the Department of Education that their safety matters.


Do not implement this rule—it will hurt America’s daughters.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
Dear Secretary Cardona,

I write to oppose the proposed Title IX rule that would completely reverse the current protections for women and girls in sports. 

This rule’s interpretation of Title IX would prohibit schools from establishing policies for sports based on biological sex. Instead, it would create uncomfortable, even dangerous, situations for student athletes, and would put teachers, staff, and coaches who care about students and the reality of biological sex in the untenable position of violating their beliefs.

The proposal, if adopted, would protect only a claimed “transgender” status, which will allow boys and men to compete on teams once reserved for girls and women. This is a blatant attempt to undermine 50 years of Title IX protections for female athletes, as well as the many states and localities that have passed legislation to protect women’s and girls’ sports. The federal government should not pressure local schools and school districts to ignore biology, safety, and fairness. 

The proposed rule would unreasonably prohibit boys-only and girls-only sports teams in elementary schools. I do not believe that the Department of Education is acting in good faith when it claims it will consider the needs of middle, high school, or college aged women and girls by requiring them to make their case and convince you to allow them to retain their sex-based rights under a reimagined Title IX. Women should not have to petition the government to in order to keep their basic rights to safety and fairness. 

The abolition of male and female categories will allow males to access private spaces previously reserved for women and girls. Coaches will be forced to supervise opposite sex young athletes in locker rooms, while girls and women will be forced to share showers, changing areas, and possibly beds or bedrooms (when traveling for games) with boys and men based on “gender identity” claims. Physical differences between boys and girls will put girls at higher risk of injury on the playing field.  Just recently, news broke of a female high school volleyball player who suffered long-term injuries last fall when she was spiked in the face by a male player on the opposing team. This young man was allowed to join the girl’s team because he identifies as a transgender female. 

Boys and girls, men and women currently have the chance to play on the teams aligned with their biological sex. Protecting women’s and girls’ sports doesn’t “ban” anyone from participating, it simply ensures that women’s sports can recognize biological reality rather than being bullied by individuals with a subjective (and often transitory) sense of “gender identity.” I oppose these changes to Title IX and object to the Biden Administration bullying schools and states by holding federal funds hostage to their transgender agenda.

I ask that you protect the integrity of women’s athletics and Title IX by withdrawing this proposed rule. 

Thank you.

Sincerely,
Jeannnina Windom

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
Dear Secretary of Education Miguel Cardona,

I support the Department of Education (“Department”) taking action to protect the rights of transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students to play school sports.  

I also urge the Department to strengthen its Title IX rule so that transgender, nonbinary, and intersex youth can access the full benefits of an education, including by playing school sports as they are. Defending this right is crucial for these students’ well-being and ability to learn without discrimination. 

Transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students experience high rates of sex discrimination and harassment at school, which is linked to poor academic and health outcomes. Affirming policies that allow students to play sports consistent with their gender can reduce stigma, depression, and isolation, and contribute to positive academic outcomes like fewer absences, better grades, and higher chances of completing high school.   

Transgender, nonbinary, and intersex youth need and deserve an opportunity to play school sports alongside their peers. This is especially the case in contexts that are primarily about the social, educational, and physical benefits of sport, rather than elite competition.  

Therefore, the Department should make clear that restrictions on transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students’ ability to play sports are never permitted at the K-12 or club college level. 

Transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students have been playing sports with their peers for years and with zero problems! In fact, barring trans women and girls from playing with other women and girls harms all women and girls because it can allow anyone to accuse any student athlete of not “really” being a woman or a girl.  Many times, this leads to “sex testing,” which includes horrific and invasive practices like genital inspections or hormonal tests for students to “prove” their gender. 
 
The Department should explicitly state that requiring sex testing of student athletes violates Title IX because such testing causes significant harm to affected students and is never necessary to advance an important educational objective. Sex testing invades students' privacy, is often enforced arbitrarily based on prejudice, and sends deeply stigmatizing and damaging messages to all youth that are completely inconsistent with a supportive educational environment. 
 
Discriminating against and demonizing some students because of who they are or how they look directly violates Title IX. I urge the Department to finalize and strengthen the Department’s Title IX rule to provide strong, clear protections for transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students to participate fully in sports consistent with their gender identity.

Sincerely,
Lynn Shoemaker
Whitewater, WI 53190

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
The Biden Administrations proposed rule attempts to intimidate schools into letting student athletes play on sports teams that fit their gender identity. This inclusion put students in danger by allowing biological males to not only play on young girls' sports teams, but also use their locker rooms. This does not just violate the principle of fairness; it puts our daughters in danger. 

Unfortunately, this proposed policy completely disregards biology and ignores the fact that male bodies are naturally bigger and stronger than female bodies - which creates an unfair advantage when they compete in athletics. This means that male-bodied students could easily dominate female-bodied ones on a sports team and thus rob women of potential scholarships or awards - along with making it harder for them to get accepted into college or other athletic programs down the road.  

Furthermore, this policy puts our daughters in danger by allowing biological males access to their locker rooms. Not only does this violate privacy concerns but it can also put girls at risk of physical harm if a male-bodied student were to enter a locker room and harass or assault them while they were changing clothes or showering. There have already been instances where this has happened and until we can ensure that all locker rooms are safe from potential predators, these policies should not be implemented.

Comment:
This new rule (which proposes a more inclusive approach to athletics) allows students to play on teams based on their gender identity, not their biology. It also requires schools receiving federal fundswhich includes schools in all states and at all levelsto provide access to locker rooms and other spaces consistent with a students gender identity.

The problem is that this rule (if implemented) could lead to biological males competing against young girls in sports. Given the size, bone density, and muscle mass differentials between the biological sexes, this creates a significant (and unfair) advantage for biological males who have transitioned. So while the Biden administration is trying to promote fairness, it will likely have the opposite effect.

Additionally, allowing biological males into female sports leagues could make it impossible for female athletes to find success, as those athletes would be competing against people who have superior physical strength due to higher levels of testosterone.
This isn't just unfair; it's also dangerous. If a biological male were allowed into a female locker room, young women could be put at risk of assault or harassment. 

This proposed rule change and the corresponding push for gender inclusion in sports might be well-intentioned but it certainly misguided. As a result, the Biden Administration should not move forward with this new rule!

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601

Therefore, I urge you to consider both the immediate and long-term effects of such policies on the safety and well-being of our daughters when making your decisions regarding educational policy implementation.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
I am writing to voice my deep concern over the Biden Administration's proposed rule which will intimidate schools into adopting policies that will allow biological males to play in young girls' sports, as well as use their locker rooms. These policies not only violate the spirit of equality, but also put our daughters in danger.

School districts will likely err on the side of 'inclusion' to avoid losing access to federal funding. However, this short-sighted approach ignores very real and serious risks that come with implementing such policies.

First and foremost, allowing biologically male athletes into girls' athletic programs destroys any hope of fair competition. It puts female athletes at a distinct disadvantage due to physical strength and size variances, which undermines the integrity of school athletics as a whole. 

Additionally, it also presents a unique risk  that grown men would be able to use women's locker rooms and showers. This poses significant dangers for female students in terms of their privacy and safety due to potential sexual misconduct or predatory behavior from male students or other adults with access to locker rooms or similar areas at school.

It is unacceptable for our educational institutions to prioritize student inclusivity over student safety. Our children should be able to enjoy a safe learning environment without having their rights or safety compromised by ill-conceived rules designed around political correctness rather than common sense.

Therefore, I urge you to consider both the immediate and long-term effects of such policies on the safety and well-being of our daughters when making your decisions regarding educational policy implementation.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
I strongly oppose the Department of Education’s proposed rule that threatens to withhold funding for children’s education in exchange for accepting someone else’s “adopted” sexual identity.

The biology between male and female is undeniably inherent and distinct to each sex, giving males, specifically, physical characteristics that make them naturally dominant over females in most sports.

The department’s proposal creates an unfair advantage to males and undermines girls’ and women’s sports.

I urge the Department of Education to recognize the differences and stop placating the movement to destroy the true equality that women have worked so hard to achieve.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
I am writing in opposition to this rule. It puts women on defense, forcing them to justify a right to their own sports and their own spaces.

My daughter played women's volleyball & basketball throughout college and since then has coach high schoolers in both sports plus has been a full time  college volleyball head coach for the last 6 yrs.  Her accomplishments & stats were significantly important to get to her college of choice, & qualify for scholarships, as well as when applying for coaching positions!!  These opportunities will be destroyed for woman college athletes and coaches.  Blatantly unfair to woman in sports.

Also, at the college level, the athleticism of female athletes is strong and concussions are a common occurrence in volleyball. We've already seen dangerous and permanent brain injuries for high school females playing volleyball against males who self-identify as females to compete.  Blatantly unsafe to woman in sports.

Allowing males, no matter how they self-identify, into women’s sports erases all pretense of fairness. This rule is blatantly sexist and unfair.

This rule destroys fairness, erases women’s spaces, and eliminates opportunities for women. Protection for women’s sports were created to elevate women to a level playing field, and increase opportunities for scholarships, education, and entrance into the workforce. This rule undoes the work that came before it.

Furthermore, this rule creates a false pretense that women’s physical safety is important to the Department of Education. But any right to safety that must be justified on a case by case basis is not a right. This new rule jeopardizes women by forcing schools to try and win a bureaucratic paperfight to protect women’s sports for women. 

Instead of focusing on their studies, homework, and sports practices, this rule puts the burden on young female athletes to spend their time advocating to their school administration and justifying to the Department of Education that their safety matters.


Do not implement this rule—it will hurt America’s daughters.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
I am writing to express my deep concern over the Department of Educations attempt to intimidate schools into allowing biological males to play in young girls' sports, as well as use their locker rooms. These policies not only violate the spirit of equality, but also put our daughters in danger.

Without a doubt, institutions will feel obligated to come down on the side of 'inclusion' in order to avoid losing access to federal tax dollars. However, this short-sighted approach ignores very real and serious risks that come with implementing such policies.

Young women should have the opportunity to develop their skills and talents in a safe and supportive environment. Allowing biologically male athletes into girls' athletic programs, whether for competition or locker room usage, goes against common sense and poses a real physical risk to these young women.

I urge you to consider both the immediate and long-term effects of such policies on the safety and well-being of our daughters.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
I am writing to voice my deep concern over the Biden Administration's proposed changes. These changes will coerce schools into allowing biological males to play in young girls' sports and use their locker rooms. 


Allowing biological males into young girls sports puts female athletes at a scientifically proven physical disadvantage. Given recent history we can expect to see biologically female athletes struggle to compete with their biologically male competitors. It also exposes young girls to potential sexual misconduct or predatory behavior from male students or other adults with access to locker rooms or similar areas at school. This doesn't just violate the spirit of fairness, it also puts our daughters in danger.


While inclusion is an important value, we must also recognize that inclusion should never come at the expense of safety or fairness. 


Therefore, I urge you to take action now to protect our daughters' safety and uphold the integrity of sports competition.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
I call on the U.S. Department of Education to stop undermining the protections of Title IX for
female student athletes by coercing schools to allow men and boys to compete in womens and
girls athletics.

Forcing female athletes to compete in their chosen sports against men and boys who identify as
female will destroy a half century of progress under Title IX for women and girls. You will rob
females of spots on teams, push them off podiums to make room for males who have undeniable
biological advantages over female competitors, and deter them from competing in the first place.
This proposed rule will also cause physical harm to female athletes when they have to compete
against larger, stronger men.

The Departments proposed regulation defies Title IX, whose purpose is to provide equal
educational opportunities, including in athletics, based on sex, not gender identity. This
proposed rule denies women and girls an equal playing field in school athletics and sets the
clock back over 50 years, to the time before Congress passed Title IX.

I urge the Department to obey the law and follow common sense by withdrawing its plan to force
women and girls to compete against men and boys in the athletic arena.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
I am writing to address concerns that my family and I have regarding the newly proposed rule, “Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Sex in Education Programs or Activities Receiving Federal Financial Assistance: Sex-Related Eligibility Criteria for Male and Female Athletic Teams” (RIN  1870-AA19; Docket ID ED-2022-OCR-0143; “Proposed Rule”). This Proposed Rule undercuts states that are protecting female athletes from ongoing discrimination and leaves women without protection when male students are allowed to join their teams. In fact, the majority of states have introduced legislation to protect female athletes, and so far twenty of them have passed those protections into law. This is not a minority viewpoint: it's common sense.

Women deserve a fair shot in sports, but when males are allowed to compete in female sports contests, that fair shot disappears. Males have an undeniable biological advantage over female athletes no matter the amount of testosterone suppression is taken–but the administration will allow males to compete with females anyway if this rule is finalized. When this happens, girls and women lose out on championships, scholarships, and other opportunities meant just for them.
 
The Proposed Rule states that if schools apply “a one-size-fits-all approach, they rely on overbroad generalizations that do not account for the nature of particular sports, the level of competition at issue, and the grade or education level of students to which they apply.” Those schools using that a standard across the board would thus not be in compliance with the rule as proposed. This leaves the door open to dramatically confuse schools and states on what qualifies as legitimate reasons, such as physical harm, to keep women’s sports for biological women only.
 
I am calling on the Biden Administration to not put ideology and politics over girls and women. Please rescind this rule and make it clear for schools that women’s sports is for biological women only, as Title IX originally intended.
 
Thank you for considering this request.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
I am 100% against this nonsense.  The federal government is way out of it's lane on this.  There are only two sexes, male and female.  You can't change biology.  Stick to the science!

I strongly oppose the Department of Education’s proposed rule that threatens to withhold funding for children’s education in exchange for accepting someone else’s “adopted” sexual identity.

The biology between male and female is undeniably inherent and distinct to each sex, giving males, specifically, physical characteristics that make them naturally dominant over females in most sports.

The department’s proposal creates an unfair advantage to males and undermines girls’ and women’s sports.

I urge the Department of Education to recognize the differences and stop placating the movement to destroy the true equality that women have worked so hard to achieve.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
Dear Secretary of Education Miguel Cardona,

I support the Department of Education (“Department”) taking action to protect the rights of transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students to play school sports.  

I also urge the Department to strengthen its Title IX rule so that transgender, nonbinary, and intersex youth can access the full benefits of an education, including by playing school sports as they are. Defending this right is crucial for these students’ well-being and ability to learn without discrimination. 

Transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students experience high rates of sex discrimination and harassment at school, which is linked to poor academic and health outcomes. Affirming policies that allow students to play sports consistent with their gender can reduce stigma, depression, and isolation, and contribute to positive academic outcomes like fewer absences, better grades, and higher chances of completing high school.   

Transgender, nonbinary, and intersex youth need and deserve an opportunity to play school sports alongside their peers. This is especially the case in contexts that are primarily about the social, educational, and physical benefits of sport, rather than elite competition.  

Therefore, the Department should make clear that restrictions on transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students’ ability to play sports are never permitted at the K-12 or club college level. 

Transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students have been playing sports with their peers for years and with zero problems! In fact, barring trans women and girls from playing with other women and girls harms all women and girls because it can allow anyone to accuse any student athlete of not “really” being a woman or a girl.  Many times, this leads to “sex testing,” which includes horrific and invasive practices like genital inspections or hormonal tests for students to “prove” their gender. 
 
The Department should explicitly state that requiring sex testing of student athletes violates Title IX because such testing causes significant harm to affected students and is never necessary to advance an important educational objective. Sex testing invades students' privacy, is often enforced arbitrarily based on prejudice, and sends deeply stigmatizing and damaging messages to all youth that are completely inconsistent with a supportive educational environment. 
 
Discriminating against and demonizing some students because of who they are or how they look directly violates Title IX. I urge the Department to finalize and strengthen the Department’s Title IX rule to provide strong, clear protections for transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students to participate fully in sports consistent with their gender identity.

Sincerely,
Helen Hansen
Oceanside, CA 92057

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
The Biden Administrations proposed rule attempts to intimidate schools into letting student athletes play on sports teams that fit their gender identity. This inclusion put students in danger by allowing biological males to not only play on young girls' sports teams, but also use their locker rooms. This does not just violate the principle of fairness; it puts our daughters in danger. 

Unfortunately, this proposed policy completely disregards biology and ignores the fact that male bodies are naturally bigger and stronger than female bodies - which creates an unfair advantage when they compete in athletics. This means that male-bodied students could easily dominate female-bodied ones on a sports team and thus rob women of potential scholarships or awards - along with making it harder for them to get accepted into college or other athletic programs down the road.  

Furthermore, this policy puts our daughters in danger by allowing biological males access to their locker rooms. Not only does this violate privacy concerns but it can also put girls at risk of physical harm if a male-bodied student were to enter a locker room and harass or assault them while they were changing clothes or showering. There have already been instances where this has happened and until we can ensure that all locker rooms are safe from potential predators, these policies should not be implemented.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
Dear Secretary Cardona,

I write to oppose the proposed Title IX rule that would completely reverse the current protections for women and girls in sports. 

This rule’s interpretation of Title IX would prohibit schools from establishing policies for sports based on biological sex. Instead, it would create uncomfortable, even dangerous, situations for student athletes, and would put teachers, staff, and coaches who care about students and the reality of biological sex in the untenable position of violating their beliefs.

The proposal, if adopted, would protect only a claimed “transgender” status, which will allow boys and men to compete on teams once reserved for girls and women. This is a blatant attempt to undermine 50 years of Title IX protections for female athletes, as well as the many states and localities that have passed legislation to protect women’s and girls’ sports. The federal government should not pressure local schools and school districts to ignore biology, safety, and fairness. 

The proposed rule would unreasonably prohibit boys-only and girls-only sports teams in elementary schools. I do not believe that the Department of Education is acting in good faith when it claims it will consider the needs of middle, high school, or college aged women and girls by requiring them to make their case and convince you to allow them to retain their sex-based rights under a reimagined Title IX. Women should not have to petition the government to in order to keep their basic rights to safety and fairness. 

The abolition of male and female categories will allow males to access private spaces previously reserved for women and girls. Coaches will be forced to supervise opposite sex young athletes in locker rooms, while girls and women will be forced to share showers, changing areas, and possibly beds or bedrooms (when traveling for games) with boys and men based on “gender identity” claims. Physical differences between boys and girls will put girls at higher risk of injury on the playing field.  Just recently, news broke of a female high school volleyball player who suffered long-term injuries last fall when she was spiked in the face by a male player on the opposing team. This young man was allowed to join the girl’s team because he identifies as a transgender female. 

Boys and girls, men and women currently have the chance to play on the teams aligned with their biological sex. Protecting women’s and girls’ sports doesn’t “ban” anyone from participating, it simply ensures that women’s sports can recognize biological reality rather than being bullied by individuals with a subjective (and often transitory) sense of “gender identity.” I oppose these changes to Title IX and object to the Biden Administration bullying schools and states by holding federal funds hostage to their transgender agenda.

I ask that you protect the integrity of women’s athletics and Title IX by withdrawing this proposed rule. 

Thank you.

Sincerely,
Shannon Wiedeman
