Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
As a female, I am deeple disturbed, yroubled and offended by the Biden Administration's proposed policy that would allow biological males who identify as female to participate in girls' sports in schools. While this may seem like an act of inclusion, it flies completely in the face of the original intent, protections, and opportunities Title IX offered.  In the words of Riley Gaines, "It is not kind to put a man in a women's locker room, and it is not inclusive to allow a man to take opportunities away from women. 

These changes will negatively impact female athletes who will be forced to compete against biological males who are physically stronger and faster than they are. This creates an unfair playing field for young girls and women alike, and will hinder their ability to compete at a high level. 

Additionally, instituting such policies could put young female students at risk in other ways. For example, allowing male-identifying individuals into girls' locker rooms would create an uncomfortable and potentially dangerous environment for many young women who simply want privacy when changing clothes or showering after physical activity. It's not only unfair but unsafe for them too.

Aside from these safety issues, what's particularly troubling about this situation is how little transparency there has been regarding the specifics of such a policy. The Biden Administration has made vague statements regarding "inclusion" but hasn't clarified what exactly that entails or how it will be enforcedleaving students and institutions in limbo while they wait for further information from the government. To make matters worse, many schools feel pressured into acquiescing since they don't want to be denied federal funding.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
I am writing to express my concerns about the limitations of the proposed rule changes to Title IX regarding the inclusion of transgender athletes. The Department of Education's efforts to protect transgender students in the wake of continued legislative threats are commendable. However, without revision the policy would fall short of meeting U.S. Secretary of Education Miguel Cardona's vision for every student having the "full experience of attending school in America, including participating in athletics, free from discrimination."

While the policy change would bar one-size-fits-all discriminatory policies, it leaves many high school and college transgender athletes on the sidelines. As it stands, the policy creates a clear pathway to legitimize discrimination by citing "educational objectives." The rule would subject transgender athletes to exceptional scrutiny and increase the likelihood of exclusion in athletics as they nurture their talents and enter competitive spaces. It would require transgender athletes to challenge pretextual exclusionary criteria at the expense of valuable training, playing time, and their own mental and physical wellbeing.

The Department should adopt rules to guarantee non-discrimination for transgender students by providing explicit protections for transgender students at all levels of competition. This includes the presumption of full inclusion for transgender athletes, as well as realistically attainable pathways for transgender students to participate in the sport that aligns with their gender identity at all levels of competition.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
The Department of Education (DoEd) recently released a memo that attempts to intimidate schools into allowing biological males who identify as female to participate in womens sports. This would mean that the male athletes have access to locker rooms and other facilities that were made specifically for female athletes. Not only does this go against the spirit of fairness, but it also puts our daughters at risk of harm and abuse. Lets look at why this policy is dangerous and wrong. 


By letting biological males compete with girls in sports, the Biden Administration is essentially erasing any trace of fairness or safety for female athletes. It sets a precedent for young girls that their hard work and dedication are not enough, since they will be competing against someone who has an advantage over them. Furthermore, it puts these young girls in a compromising position by allowing biological males to use the same locker rooms as them. This opens up the possibility of sexual assault and other forms of harassment or abuse from people who do not share the same biological gender. 


It is important to note that this policy directly contradicts Title IX, which was passed in 1972 to promote equal opportunities for men and women in education, including athletics. Allowing biological males to compete with females goes against one of its primary goalsthat men and women should have equal access to sporting activities without discrimination based on sex. If enacted this policy sets a dangerous precedent that will undermine Title IXs original intent and put womens rights at risk. 


The DoEds policy regarding biological males playing in female sports is dangerous and wrong on many levels. It undermines fairness by giving male athletes an advantage over their female counterparts, compromises safety by allowing male athletes access to female locker rooms, and violates Title IX by promoting discrimination based on gender identity rather than sex. We must stand up for what is rightfairness, safety, and equalityand speak out against policies like these that put our daughters at risk!   Please do not move forward with the proposed changes.  Think of your daughters and your granddaughter, what will this do to them?  It will erase them and all that so many that came before did to gain some equality for woman.  To be a fair competition is has to be biological women against biological.  Cmon man, follow the science!!

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
Dear Secretary Cardona,

I write to oppose the proposed Title IX rule that would completely reverse the current protections for women and girls in sports. 

This rule’s interpretation of Title IX would prohibit schools from establishing policies for sports based on biological sex. Instead, it would create uncomfortable, even dangerous, situations for student athletes, and would put teachers, staff, and coaches who care about students and the reality of biological sex in the untenable position of violating their beliefs.

The proposal, if adopted, would protect only a claimed “transgender” status, which will allow boys and men to compete on teams once reserved for girls and women. This is a blatant attempt to undermine 50 years of Title IX protections for female athletes, as well as the many states and localities that have passed legislation to protect women’s and girls’ sports. The federal government should not pressure local schools and school districts to ignore biology, safety, and fairness. 

The proposed rule would unreasonably prohibit boys-only and girls-only sports teams in elementary schools. I do not believe that the Department of Education is acting in good faith when it claims it will consider the needs of middle, high school, or college aged women and girls by requiring them to make their case and convince you to allow them to retain their sex-based rights under a reimagined Title IX. Women should not have to petition the government to in order to keep their basic rights to safety and fairness. 

The abolition of male and female categories will allow males to access private spaces previously reserved for women and girls. Coaches will be forced to supervise opposite sex young athletes in locker rooms, while girls and women will be forced to share showers, changing areas, and possibly beds or bedrooms (when traveling for games) with boys and men based on “gender identity” claims. Physical differences between boys and girls will put girls at higher risk of injury on the playing field.  Just recently, news broke of a female high school volleyball player who suffered long-term injuries last fall when she was spiked in the face by a male player on the opposing team. This young man was allowed to join the girl’s team because he identifies as a transgender female. 

Boys and girls, men and women currently have the chance to play on the teams aligned with their biological sex. Protecting women’s and girls’ sports doesn’t “ban” anyone from participating, it simply ensures that women’s sports can recognize biological reality rather than being bullied by individuals with a subjective (and often transitory) sense of “gender identity.” I oppose these changes to Title IX and object to the Biden Administration bullying schools and states by holding federal funds hostage to their transgender agenda.

I ask that you protect the integrity of women’s athletics and Title IX by withdrawing this proposed rule. 

Thank you.

Sincerely,
Jan Donohue

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601

The Biden Administrations proposed change to Title IX claims to promote equality by allowing students to participate in sports based on their gender identity, not their biological sex. While this may seem like a win for fairness and inclusion, it violates the spirit of fairness that underpins women's athletics. Schools should not be incentivized by federal tax dollars to allow policies that put our children in harm's way. This is unacceptable! 

It is important to note that this policy does not just threaten fairness or put our daughters at risk, it also tramples on womens rights in general. A policy that permits biological males to enter female spaces, sends girls a message that their bodies do not matter as much as those of male-identifying individuals, and that women are second-class citizens. This undermines decades of progress made towards gender equality and equal rights for both sexes.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
I am writing to address concerns that my family and I have regarding the newly proposed rule, “Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Sex in Education Programs or Activities Receiving Federal Financial Assistance: Sex-Related Eligibility Criteria for Male and Female Athletic Teams” (RIN  1870-AA19; Docket ID ED-2022-OCR-0143; “Proposed Rule”). This Proposed Rule undercuts states that are protecting female athletes from ongoing discrimination and leaves women without protection when male students are allowed to join their teams. In fact, the majority of states have introduced legislation to protect female athletes, and so far twenty of them have passed those protections into law. This is not a minority viewpoint: it's common sense.

Women deserve a fair shot in sports, but when males are allowed to compete in female sports contests, that fair shot disappears. Males have an undeniable biological advantage over female athletes no matter the amount of testosterone suppression is taken–but the administration will allow males to compete with females anyway if this rule is finalized. When this happens, girls and women lose out on championships, scholarships, and other opportunities meant just for them.
 
The Proposed Rule states that if schools apply “a one-size-fits-all approach, they rely on overbroad generalizations that do not account for the nature of particular sports, the level of competition at issue, and the grade or education level of students to which they apply.” Those schools using that a standard across the board would thus not be in compliance with the rule as proposed. This leaves the door open to dramatically confuse schools and states on what qualifies as legitimate reasons, such as physical harm, to keep women’s sports for biological women only.
 
I am calling on the Biden Administration to not put ideology and politics over girls and women. Please rescind this rule and make it clear for schools that women’s sports is for biological women only, as Title IX originally intended.
 
Thank you for considering this request.

Therefore, I urge you to take action now to protect our daughters' safety and uphold the integrity of sports competition by stopping this attempted policy change.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
Dear Secretary of Education Miguel Cardona,

I support the Department of Education (“Department”) taking action to protect the rights of transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students to play school sports.  

I also urge the Department to strengthen its Title IX rule so that transgender, nonbinary, and intersex youth can access the full benefits of an education, including by playing school sports as they are. Defending this right is crucial for these students’ well-being and ability to learn without discrimination. 

Transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students experience high rates of sex discrimination and harassment at school, which is linked to poor academic and health outcomes. Affirming policies that allow students to play sports consistent with their gender can reduce stigma, depression, and isolation, and contribute to positive academic outcomes like fewer absences, better grades, and higher chances of completing high school.   

Transgender, nonbinary, and intersex youth need and deserve an opportunity to play school sports alongside their peers. This is especially the case in contexts that are primarily about the social, educational, and physical benefits of sport, rather than elite competition.  

Therefore, the Department should make clear that restrictions on transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students’ ability to play sports are never permitted at the K-12 or club college level. 

Transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students have been playing sports with their peers for years and with zero problems! In fact, barring trans women and girls from playing with other women and girls harms all women and girls because it can allow anyone to accuse any student athlete of not “really” being a woman or a girl.  Many times, this leads to “sex testing,” which includes horrific and invasive practices like genital inspections or hormonal tests for students to “prove” their gender. 
 
The Department should explicitly state that requiring sex testing of student athletes violates Title IX because such testing causes significant harm to affected students and is never necessary to advance an important educational objective. Sex testing invades students' privacy, is often enforced arbitrarily based on prejudice, and sends deeply stigmatizing and damaging messages to all youth that are completely inconsistent with a supportive educational environment. 
 
Discriminating against and demonizing some students because of who they are or how they look directly violates Title IX. I urge the Department to finalize and strengthen the Department’s Title IX rule to provide strong, clear protections for transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students to participate fully in sports consistent with their gender identity.

Sincerely,
Joanne LaVine
Mustang, OK 73064

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
I strongly oppose the Department of Education’s proposed rule that threatens to withhold funding for children’s education in exchange for accepting someone else’s “adopted” sexual identity.
Biological males do not belong in womens sports and they certainly do not belong in the womens dressing room. This is an absurd bill which is catering to a small minority, while making a sham of all the rights that women have worked so hard to achieve.
The department’s proposal creates an unfair advantage to males and undermines girls’ and women’s sports.

I urge the Department of Education to recognize the differences and stop placating the movement to destroy the true equality that women have worked so hard to achieve.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
I strongly oppose the Department of Education’s proposed rule that threatens to withhold funding for children’s education in exchange for accepting someone else’s “adopted” sexual identity.

The department’s proposal creates an unfair advantage to males and undermines girls’ and women’s sports.

I urge the Department of Education to recognize the differences and stop placating the movement to destroy the true equality that women have worked so hard to achieve.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
I call on the U.S. Department of Education to stop undermining the protections of Title IX for
female student athletes by coercing schools to allow men and boys to compete in womens and
girls athletics.

Forcing female athletes to compete in their chosen sports against men and boys who identify as
female will destroy a half century of progress under Title IX for women and girls. You will rob
females of spots on teams, push them off podiums to make room for males who have undeniable
biological advantages over female competitors, and deter them from competing in the first place.
This proposed rule will also cause physical harm to female athletes when they have to compete
against larger, stronger men.

The Departments proposed regulation defies Title IX, whose purpose is to provide equal
educational opportunities, including in athletics, based on sex, not gender identity. This
proposed rule denies women and girls an equal playing field in school athletics and sets the
clock back over 50 years, to the time before Congress passed Title IX.

I urge the Department to obey the law and follow common sense by withdrawing its plan to force
women and girls to compete against men and boys in the athletic arena.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
Dear Secretary of Education Miguel Cardona,

I support the Department of Education (“Department”) taking action to protect the rights of transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students to play school sports.  

I also urge the Department to strengthen its Title IX rule so that transgender, nonbinary, and intersex youth can access the full benefits of an education, including by playing school sports as they are. Defending this right is crucial for these students’ well-being and ability to learn without discrimination. 

Transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students experience high rates of sex discrimination and harassment at school, which is linked to poor academic and health outcomes. Affirming policies that allow students to play sports consistent with their gender can reduce stigma, depression, and isolation, and contribute to positive academic outcomes like fewer absences, better grades, and higher chances of completing high school.   

Transgender, nonbinary, and intersex youth need and deserve an opportunity to play school sports alongside their peers. This is especially the case in contexts that are primarily about the social, educational, and physical benefits of sport, rather than elite competition.  

Therefore, the Department should make clear that restrictions on transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students’ ability to play sports are never permitted at the K-12 or club college level. 

Transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students have been playing sports with their peers for years and with zero problems! In fact, barring trans women and girls from playing with other women and girls harms all women and girls because it can allow anyone to accuse any student athlete of not “really” being a woman or a girl.  Many times, this leads to “sex testing,” which includes horrific and invasive practices like genital inspections or hormonal tests for students to “prove” their gender. 
 
The Department should explicitly state that requiring sex testing of student athletes violates Title IX because such testing causes significant harm to affected students and is never necessary to advance an important educational objective. Sex testing invades students' privacy, is often enforced arbitrarily based on prejudice, and sends deeply stigmatizing and damaging messages to all youth that are completely inconsistent with a supportive educational environment. 
 
Discriminating against and demonizing some students because of who they are or how they look directly violates Title IX. I urge the Department to finalize and strengthen the Department’s Title IX rule to provide strong, clear protections for transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students to participate fully in sports consistent with their gender identity.
We need to be emphatic about getting a message of truthful information out to all Americans. No one asks to be transgender & the suffering transgenders undergo is shameful and unnecessary. Thank you.


Sincerely,
Jo-Ann Sramek
Duluth, MN 55811

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
I am writing to voice my deep concern over the Biden Administration's proposed changes that would force my school district to allow biological males to play in young girls' sports and use their locker rooms. This policy presents serious risks to students' safety and undermines the spirit of fairness in athletics.

Allowing biological males into young girls sports puts female athletes at a distinct physical disadvantage. And this truly eliminates any hope of fair competition. Furthermore, it also exposes young women to potential sexual misconduct or predatory behavior from biologically male students or other adults with access to locker rooms or similar areas at school. 


This doesn't just violate the spirit of fairness, it also puts our daughters in danger!


Therefore, I urge you to take action now to protect our daughters' safety and uphold the integrity of sports competition by stopping this attempted policy change.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
The Department of Educations  proposed rule attempts to intimidate school districts into allowing biological males who identify as female to participate in womens sports. This would mean that the male athletes have access to locker rooms and other facilities that were made specifically for female athletes. Not only does this go against the spirit of fairness, but it also puts our daughters at risk of harm and abuse. 


By letting biological males compete with girls in sports, the Biden Administration is erasing any trace of fairness or safety for female athletes. It sets a precedent for young girls that their hard work and dedication are not enough, since they will be competing against someone who has a physiological advantage over them. Furthermore, it puts these young girls in a compromising position by allowing biological males to use the same locker rooms as them. This opens up the possibility of sexual assault and other forms of harassment or abuse from people who do not share the same biological sex. 


This policy directly contradicts the very purpose of Title IX, which was passed in 1972 to promote equal opportunities for men and women in education, including athletics. Allowing biological males to compete with females goes against one of its primary goalsthat men and women should have equal access to sporting activities without discrimination based on sex. If enacted this policy sets a dangerous precedent that will undermine Title IXs original intent and put womens rights at risk. 


The Education Departments  proposed policy is dangerous and wrong on many levels. It undermines fairness by giving male-bodied athletes an advantage over their female-bodied counterparts, compromises safety by allowing male-bodied athletes access to female locker rooms, and violates Title IX by promoting discrimination based on gender identity rather than sex. This policy puts our daughters at risk.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
I am writing to address concerns that my family and I have regarding the newly proposed rule, “Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Sex in Education Programs or Activities Receiving Federal Financial Assistance: Sex-Related Eligibility Criteria for Male and Female Athletic Teams” (RIN  1870-AA19; Docket ID ED-2022-OCR-0143; “Proposed Rule”). This Proposed Rule undercuts states that are protecting female athletes from ongoing discrimination and leaves women without protection when male students are allowed to join their teams. In fact, the majority of states have introduced legislation to protect female athletes, and so far twenty of them have passed those protections into law. This is not a minority viewpoint: it's common sense.

Women deserve a fair shot in sports, but when males are allowed to compete in female sports contests, that fair shot disappears. Males have an undeniable biological advantage over female athletes no matter the amount of testosterone suppression is taken–but the administration will allow males to compete with females anyway if this rule is finalized. When this happens, girls and women lose out on championships, scholarships, and other opportunities meant just for them.
 
The Proposed Rule states that if schools apply “a one-size-fits-all approach, they rely on overbroad generalizations that do not account for the nature of particular sports, the level of competition at issue, and the grade or education level of students to which they apply.” Those schools using that a standard across the board would thus not be in compliance with the rule as proposed. This leaves the door open to dramatically confuse schools and states on what qualifies as legitimate reasons, such as physical harm, to keep women’s sports for biological women only.
 
I am calling on the Biden Administration to not put ideology and politics over girls and women. Please rescind this rule and make it clear for schools that women’s sports is for biological women only, as Title IX originally intended.
 
Thank you for considering this request.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
This new rule (which proposes a more inclusive approach to athletics) allows students to play on teams based on their gender identity, not their biology. It also requires schools receiving federal fundswhich includes schools in all states and at all levelsto provide access to locker rooms and other spaces consistent with a students gender identity.

The problem is that this rule (if implemented) could lead to biological males competing against young girls in sports. Given the size, bone density, and muscle mass differentials between the biological sexes, this creates a significant (and unfair) advantage for biological males who have transitioned. So while the Biden administration is trying to promote fairness, it will likely have the opposite effect.

Additionally, allowing biological males into female sports leagues could make it impossible for female athletes to find success, as those athletes would be competing against people who have superior physical strength due to higher levels of testosterone.
This isn't just unfair; it's also dangerous. If a biological male were allowed into a female locker room, young women could be put at risk of assault or harassment. 

This proposed rule change and the corresponding push for gender inclusion in sports might be well-intentioned but it certainly misguided. As a result, the Biden Administration should not move forward with this new rule!

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
I am writing to express my deep concern over the Department of Educations attempt to intimidate schools into allowing biological males to play in young girls' sports, as well as use their locker rooms. These policies not only violate the spirit of equality, but also put our daughters in danger.

Without a doubt, institutions will feel obligated to come down on the side of 'inclusion' in order to avoid losing access to federal tax dollars. However, this short-sighted approach ignores very real and serious risks that come with implementing such policies.

Young women should have the opportunity to develop their skills and talents in a safe and supportive environment. Allowing biologically male athletes into girls' athletic programs, whether for competition or locker room usage, goes against common sense and poses a real physical risk to these young women.

I urge you to consider both the immediate and long-term effects of such policies on the safety and well-being of our daughters.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
Dear Secretary Cardona,

I write to oppose the proposed Title IX rule that would completely reverse the current protections for women and girls in sports. 

This rule’s interpretation of Title IX would prohibit schools from establishing policies for sports based on biological sex. Instead, it would create uncomfortable, even dangerous, situations for student athletes, and would put teachers, staff, and coaches who care about students and the reality of biological sex in the untenable position of violating their beliefs.

The proposal, if adopted, would protect only a claimed “transgender” status, which will allow boys and men to compete on teams once reserved for girls and women. This is a blatant attempt to undermine 50 years of Title IX protections for female athletes, as well as the many states and localities that have passed legislation to protect women’s and girls’ sports. The federal government should not pressure local schools and school districts to ignore biology, safety, and fairness. 

The proposed rule would unreasonably prohibit boys-only and girls-only sports teams in elementary schools. I do not believe that the Department of Education is acting in good faith when it claims it will consider the needs of middle, high school, or college aged women and girls by requiring them to make their case and convince you to allow them to retain their sex-based rights under a reimagined Title IX. Women should not have to petition the government to in order to keep their basic rights to safety and fairness. 

The abolition of male and female categories will allow males to access private spaces previously reserved for women and girls. Coaches will be forced to supervise opposite sex young athletes in locker rooms, while girls and women will be forced to share showers, changing areas, and possibly beds or bedrooms (when traveling for games) with boys and men based on “gender identity” claims. Physical differences between boys and girls will put girls at higher risk of injury on the playing field.  Just recently, news broke of a female high school volleyball player who suffered long-term injuries last fall when she was spiked in the face by a male player on the opposing team. This young man was allowed to join the girl’s team because he identifies as a transgender female. 

Boys and girls, men and women currently have the chance to play on the teams aligned with their biological sex. Protecting women’s and girls’ sports doesn’t “ban” anyone from participating, it simply ensures that women’s sports can recognize biological reality rather than being bullied by individuals with a subjective (and often transitory) sense of “gender identity.” I oppose these changes to Title IX and object to the Biden Administration bullying schools and states by holding federal funds hostage to their transgender agenda.

I ask that you protect the integrity of women’s athletics and Title IX by withdrawing this proposed rule. 

Thank you.

Sincerely,
Barry Watkins

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment: Why doesn't my little girl get to have a fair shot to compete? Why does she suffer the consequences of our institutions ignoring obvious physiological advantages enjoyed by male-to-female trans athletes? It is wrong. Our society has finally reached a point where the weaker sex is able to pursue opportunities and achieve heights never thought possible before. Yet, in the last handful of years that reality has dissolved and to even dare protest it, for their sake, is deemed hateful. If these changes go into effect, not only will you allow a theft of opportunity and progress for women, but you will compromise the safety of our girls. When is someone going to defend them?

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
Dear Miguel Cardona,

I believe that all trans, intersex, and nonbinary youth of all ages should have the equal, fair, and full opportunity to participate in sports–including at the college level–under Title IX. No young person should ever be excluded just because of who they are–especially students who just want to play sports. . Participating in sports gives young people of all backgrounds an opportunity to learn and play, be part of a team, and nurture relationships. The memories and life lessons gained from playing with your peers are priceless. There are few spaces in a young person’s life that cultivate and create the countless memories and life lessons that sports provide, and excluding any young individual would be unfair and unjust. I hope all kids are able to participate in all the sports they would like to explore. Please finalize a Title IX rule that allows all young people to play!

I urge the Department of Education to protect those most impacted by this rule: trans, intersex, and nonbinary youth. All children need to play in order to grow. Limiting play is destructive and hateful. Children thrive in loving, supportive environments. 

I support the full inclusion of all students and youth in school sports and activities, including transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students–from kindergarten through college. I urge the Department of Education to finalize a Title IX rule that protects the right of students of all ages to participate in sports in every state in the country. Thank you for your consideration

Sincerely,
H J
VA

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
My name is Gretchen Kohlhepp. Im writing in regard to the Department of Educations Proposed Rule  Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Sex in Education Programs or Activities Receiving Federal Financial Assistance: Sex-Related Eligibility Criteria for Male and Female Athletic Teams (RIN:1870-AA19).

My son just wants to participate in sports with his friends!

Transgender youth, just like all youth, simply want to participate in the same educational activities as their peers, including athletics. All transgender students  at every age and in every sport  should be presumed eligible to participate in sports consistent with their gender identity. And schools should not limit a students participation on a team solely because they are transgender.

Thank you very much.
Gretchen Kohlhepp

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
Dear Secretary Cardona,

I write to oppose the proposed Title IX rule that would completely reverse the current protections for women and girls in sports. 

This rule’s interpretation of Title IX would prohibit schools from establishing policies for sports based on biological sex. Instead, it would create uncomfortable, even dangerous, situations for student athletes, and would put teachers, staff, and coaches who care about students and the reality of biological sex in the untenable position of violating their beliefs.

The proposal, if adopted, would protect only a claimed “transgender” status, which will allow boys and men to compete on teams once reserved for girls and women. This is a blatant attempt to undermine 50 years of Title IX protections for female athletes, as well as the many states and localities that have passed legislation to protect women’s and girls’ sports. The federal government should not pressure local schools and school districts to ignore biology, safety, and fairness. 

The proposed rule would unreasonably prohibit boys-only and girls-only sports teams in elementary schools. I do not believe that the Department of Education is acting in good faith when it claims it will consider the needs of middle, high school, or college aged women and girls by requiring them to make their case and convince you to allow them to retain their sex-based rights under a reimagined Title IX. Women should not have to petition the government to in order to keep their basic rights to safety and fairness. 

The abolition of male and female categories will allow males to access private spaces previously reserved for women and girls. Coaches will be forced to supervise opposite sex young athletes in locker rooms, while girls and women will be forced to share showers, changing areas, and possibly beds or bedrooms (when traveling for games) with boys and men based on “gender identity” claims. Physical differences between boys and girls will put girls at higher risk of injury on the playing field.  Just recently, news broke of a female high school volleyball player who suffered long-term injuries last fall when she was spiked in the face by a male player on the opposing team. This young man was allowed to join the girl’s team because he identifies as a transgender female. 

Boys and girls, men and women currently have the chance to play on the teams aligned with their biological sex. Protecting women’s and girls’ sports doesn’t “ban” anyone from participating, it simply ensures that women’s sports can recognize biological reality rather than being bullied by individuals with a subjective (and often transitory) sense of “gender identity.” I oppose these changes to Title IX and object to the Biden Administration bullying schools and states by holding federal funds hostage to their transgender agenda.

I ask that you protect the integrity of women’s athletics and Title IX by withdrawing this proposed rule. 

Thank you.

Sincerely,
Mary Dillard

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
Dear Secretary of Education Miguel Cardona,

I support the Department of Education (“Department”) taking action to protect the rights of transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students to play school sports.  

I also urge the Department to strengthen its Title IX rule so that transgender, nonbinary, and intersex youth can access the full benefits of an education, including by playing school sports as they are. Defending this right is crucial for these students’ well-being and ability to learn without discrimination. 

Transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students experience high rates of sex discrimination and harassment at school, which is linked to poor academic and health outcomes. Affirming policies that allow students to play sports consistent with their gender can reduce stigma, depression, and isolation, and contribute to positive academic outcomes like fewer absences, better grades, and higher chances of completing high school.   

Transgender, nonbinary, and intersex youth need and deserve an opportunity to play school sports alongside their peers. This is especially the case in contexts that are primarily about the social, educational, and physical benefits of sport, rather than elite competition.  

Therefore, the Department should make clear that restrictions on transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students’ ability to play sports are never permitted at the K-12 or club college level. 

Transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students have been playing sports with their peers for years and with zero problems! In fact, barring trans women and girls from playing with other women and girls harms all women and girls because it can allow anyone to accuse any student athlete of not “really” being a woman or a girl.  Many times, this leads to “sex testing,” which includes horrific and invasive practices like genital inspections or hormonal tests for students to “prove” their gender. 
 
The Department should explicitly state that requiring sex testing of student athletes violates Title IX because such testing causes significant harm to affected students and is never necessary to advance an important educational objective. Sex testing invades students' privacy, is often enforced arbitrarily based on prejudice, and sends deeply stigmatizing and damaging messages to all youth that are completely inconsistent with a supportive educational environment. 
 
Discriminating against and demonizing some students because of who they are or how they look directly violates Title IX. I urge the Department to finalize and strengthen the Department’s Title IX rule to provide strong, clear protections for transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students to participate fully in sports consistent with their gender identity.

Sincerely,
Ashli Skye
Rochelle, GA 31079

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
Democrats need to stop voting the party agenda and promote what the majority of Americans want. They don't want this.

I strongly oppose the Department of Education’s proposed rule that threatens to withhold funding for children’s education in exchange for accepting someone else’s “adopted” sexual identity.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
I am writing in opposition to this rule. It puts women on defense, forcing them to justify a right to their own sports and their own spaces.

Allowing males, no matter how they self-identify, into women’s sports erases all pretense of fairness. This rule is blatantly sexist and unfair.

This rule destroys fairness, erases women’s spaces, and eliminates opportunities for women. Protection for women’s sports were created to elevate women to a level playing field, and increase opportunities for scholarships, education, and entrance into the workforce. This rule undoes the work that came before it.

Furthermore, this rule creates a false pretense that women’s physical safety is important to the Department of Education. But any right to safety that must be justified on a case by case basis is not a right. This new rule jeopardizes women by forcing schools to try and win a bureaucratic paperfight to protect women’s sports for women. 

Instead of focusing on their studies, homework, and sports practices, this rule puts the burden on young female athletes to spend their time advocating to their school administration and justifying to the Department of Education that their safety matters.


Do not implement this rule—it will hurt America’s daughters.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
The Department of Educations  proposed rule attempts to intimidate school districts into allowing biological males who identify as female to participate in womens sports. This would mean that the male athletes have access to locker rooms and other facilities that were made specifically for female athletes. Not only does this go against the spirit of fairness, but it also puts our daughters at risk of harm and abuse. 


By letting biological males compete with girls in sports, the Biden Administration is erasing any trace of fairness or safety for female athletes. It sets a precedent for young girls that their hard work and dedication are not enough, since they will be competing against someone who has a physiological advantage over them. Furthermore, it puts these young girls in a compromising position by allowing biological males to use the same locker rooms as them. This opens up the possibility of sexual assault and other forms of harassment or abuse from people who do not share the same biological sex. 


This policy directly contradicts the very purpose of Title IX, which was passed in 1972 to promote equal opportunities for men and women in education, including athletics. Allowing biological males to compete with females goes against one of its primary goalsthat men and women should have equal access to sporting activities without discrimination based on sex. If enacted this policy sets a dangerous precedent that will undermine Title IXs original intent and put womens rights at risk. 


The Education Departments  proposed policy is dangerous and wrong on many levels. It undermines fairness by giving male-bodied athletes an advantage over their female-bodied counterparts, compromises safety by allowing male-bodied athletes access to female locker rooms, and violates Title IX by promoting discrimination based on gender identity rather than sex. This policy puts our daughters at risk.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
This new rule (which proposes a more inclusive approach to athletics) allows students to play on teams based on their gender identity, not their biology. It also requires schools receiving federal fundswhich includes schools in all states and at all levelsto provide access to locker rooms and other spaces consistent with a students gender identity.

The problem is that this rule (if implemented) could lead to biological males competing against young girls in sports. Given the size, bone density, and muscle mass differentials between the biological sexes, this creates a significant (and unfair) advantage for biological males who have transitioned. So while the Biden administration is trying to promote fairness, it will likely have the opposite effect.

Additionally, allowing biological males into female sports leagues could make it impossible for female athletes to find success, as those athletes would be competing against people who have superior physical strength due to higher levels of testosterone.
This isn't just unfair; it's also dangerous. If a biological male were allowed into a female locker room, young women could be put at risk of assault or harassment. 

This proposed rule change and the corresponding push for gender inclusion in sports might be well-intentioned but it certainly misguided. As a result, the Biden Administration should not move forward with this new rule!

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
I call on the U.S. Department of Education to stop undermining the protections of Title IX for
female student athletes by coercing schools to allow men and boys to compete in womens and
girls athletics.

Forcing female athletes to compete in their chosen sports against men and boys who identify as
female will destroy a half century of progress under Title IX for women and girls. You will rob
females of spots on teams, push them off podiums to make room for males who have undeniable
biological advantages over female competitors, and deter them from competing in the first place.
This proposed rule will also cause physical harm to female athletes when they have to compete
against larger, stronger men.

The Departments proposed regulation defies Title IX, whose purpose is to provide equal
educational opportunities, including in athletics, based on sex, not gender identity. This
proposed rule denies women and girls an equal playing field in school athletics and sets the
clock back over 50 years, to the time before Congress passed Title IX.

I urge the Department to obey the law and follow common sense by withdrawing its plan to force
women and girls to compete against men and boys in the athletic arena.

I agree the Biden Administration's proposed policy would allow biological males who identify as female to participate in girls' sports in schools. While this may seem like an act of inclusion, it will negatively impact female athletes who will be forced to compete against biological males who are physically stronger and faster than they are. This creates an unfair playing field for young girls and women alike, and will hinder their ability to compete at a high level. 

Additionally, instituting such policies could put young female students at risk in other ways. For example, allowing male-identifying individuals into girls' locker rooms would create an uncomfortable and potentially dangerous environment for many young women who simply want privacy when changing clothes or showering after physical activity. It's not only unfair but unsafe for them too.

Aside from these safety issues, what's particularly troubling about this situation is how little transparency there has been regarding the specifics of such a policy. The Biden Administration has made vague statements regarding "inclusion" but hasn't clarified what exactly that entails or how it will be enforcedleaving students and institutions in limbo while they wait for further information from the government. To make matters worse, many schools feel pressured into acquiescing since they don't want to be denied federal funding.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
The Department of Educations  proposed rule attempts to intimidate school districts into allowing biological males who identify as female to participate in womens sports. This would mean that the male athletes have access to locker rooms and other facilities that were made specifically for female athletes. Not only does this go against the spirit of fairness, but it also puts our daughters at risk of harm and abuse. 


By letting biological males compete with girls in sports, the Biden Administration is erasing any trace of fairness or safety for female athletes. It sets a precedent for young girls that their hard work and dedication are not enough, since they will be competing against someone who has a physiological advantage over them. Furthermore, it puts these young girls in a compromising position by allowing biological males to use the same locker rooms as them. This opens up the possibility of sexual assault and other forms of harassment or abuse from people who do not share the same biological sex. 


This policy directly contradicts the very purpose of Title IX, which was passed in 1972 to promote equal opportunities for men and women in education, including athletics. Allowing biological males to compete with females goes against one of its primary goalsthat men and women should have equal access to sporting activities without discrimination based on sex. If enacted this policy sets a dangerous precedent that will undermine Title IXs original intent and put womens rights at risk. 


The Education Departments  proposed policy is dangerous and wrong on many levels. It undermines fairness by giving male-bodied athletes an advantage over their female-bodied counterparts, compromises safety by allowing male-bodied athletes access to female locker rooms, and violates Title IX by promoting discrimination based on gender identity rather than sex. This policy puts our daughters at risk.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
Dear Secretary Cardona,

I write to oppose the proposed Title IX rule that would completely reverse the current protections for women and girls in sports. 

This rule’s interpretation of Title IX would prohibit schools from establishing policies for sports based on biological sex. Instead, it would create uncomfortable, even dangerous, situations for student athletes, and would put teachers, staff, and coaches who care about students and the reality of biological sex in the untenable position of violating their beliefs.

The proposal, if adopted, would protect only a claimed “transgender” status, which will allow boys and men to compete on teams once reserved for girls and women. This is a blatant attempt to undermine 50 years of Title IX protections for female athletes, as well as the many states and localities that have passed legislation to protect women’s and girls’ sports. The federal government should not pressure local schools and school districts to ignore biology, safety, and fairness. 

The proposed rule would unreasonably prohibit boys-only and girls-only sports teams in elementary schools. I do not believe that the Department of Education is acting in good faith when it claims it will consider the needs of middle, high school, or college aged women and girls by requiring them to make their case and convince you to allow them to retain their sex-based rights under a reimagined Title IX. Women should not have to petition the government to in order to keep their basic rights to safety and fairness. 

The abolition of male and female categories will allow males to access private spaces previously reserved for women and girls. Coaches will be forced to supervise opposite sex young athletes in locker rooms, while girls and women will be forced to share showers, changing areas, and possibly beds or bedrooms (when traveling for games) with boys and men based on “gender identity” claims. Physical differences between boys and girls will put girls at higher risk of injury on the playing field.  Just recently, news broke of a female high school volleyball player who suffered long-term injuries last fall when she was spiked in the face by a male player on the opposing team. This young man was allowed to join the girl’s team because he identifies as a transgender female. 

Boys and girls, men and women currently have the chance to play on the teams aligned with their biological sex. Protecting women’s and girls’ sports doesn’t “ban” anyone from participating, it simply ensures that women’s sports can recognize biological reality rather than being bullied by individuals with a subjective (and often transitory) sense of “gender identity.” I oppose these changes to Title IX and object to the Biden Administration bullying schools and states by holding federal funds hostage to their transgender agenda.

I ask that you protect the integrity of women’s athletics and Title IX by withdrawing this proposed rule. 

Thank you.

Sincerely,
Mr. Michael J Hutton

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
I am writing to comment on 34 CFR Part 106 [Docket ID ED–2022–OCR–0143] RIN 1870–AA19 Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Sex in Education Programs or Activities Receiving Federal Financial Assistance: Sex-Related Eligibility Criteria for Male and Female Athletic Teams, published on April 13, 2023. 

I am glad to see that the Department: (1) is no longer proposing to redefine sex to include “gender identity;” and (2) now appears to acknowledge the material reality of sex.

I oppose any efforts to redefine sex to include the nebulous category of “gender identity.” All federal efforts to redefine sex to include “gender identity,” including the Department’s July 2022 proposal, rely on the Biden Administration’s repeated mischaracterizations of the Supreme Court’s decision in the matter of Bostock v. Clayton County. 

I have several concerns with the Department’s most recent approach to amending the Title IX regulations. A federal district court has recently ruled that states (and the schools within them) may, consistent with both Title IX and the Equal Protection Clause of the Constitution, maintain single-sex sports. The Department cannot, as a matter of law, prohibit schools from doing something that the Constitution and federal law permit them to do. 

Schools can and should take into account differences in grade and education level, level of competition, and sports for purposes of determining which teams ought to be mixed sex. For example, it might be appropriate for schools to designate teams as mixed sex if there is a small number of girls who want to participate on a particular team but there are not enough such girls to create a female-only team. In such instances, and considering grade level and level of competition, mixed-sex teams might be appropriate. This should not, however, have anything to do with “gender identity.” 

The Department should not be perpetuating the preposterous and extremely dangerous idea that children in elementary school have “gender identities,” even if some teenagers and adults claim to. Stop indoctrinating children with anti-science nonsense. 

The Department is now acknowledging the material reality of sex, which is good. But it should not assume that “gender identity” is a coherent concept that might, under some circumstances, be permitted to obscure the material reality of sex. The Department should also not expect schools to understand how to navigate all of this even if they want to maintain single-sex sports, which Title IX and the Constitution permit them to do.

Maintaining female-only sports is always substantially related to the achievement of an important educational objective (the inherent purpose of Title IX).

As for “minimizing harms to students whose opportunity to participate on a male or female team consistent with the gender identity would be limited or denied,” I urge the Department to understand that it is always appropriate to minimize harms to students who are confused about their sex (harms that the Department is partially responsible for causing) by helping them to accept themselves as they are – female or male.

There are few spaces in a young person’s life that cultivate and create the countless memories and life lessons that sports provide, and excluding any young individual would be unfair and unjust. I urge the Department of Education to protect those most impacted by this rule: trans, intersex, and nonbinary youth because...

I support the full inclusion of all students and youth in school sports and activities, including transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students–from kindergarten through college. I urge the Department of Education to finalize a Title IX rule that protects the right of students of all ages to participate in sports in every state in the country. Thank you for your consideration

Lansdowne, PA 19050

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
Dear Secretary of Education Miguel Cardona,

I support the Department of Education (“Department”) taking action to protect the rights of transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students to play school sports.  

I also urge the Department to strengthen its Title IX rule so that transgender, nonbinary, and intersex youth can access the full benefits of an education, including by playing school sports as they are. Defending this right is crucial for these students’ well-being and ability to learn without discrimination. 

Transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students experience high rates of sex discrimination and harassment at school, which is linked to poor academic and health outcomes. Affirming policies that allow students to play sports consistent with their gender can reduce stigma, depression, and isolation, and contribute to positive academic outcomes like fewer absences, better grades, and higher chances of completing high school.   

Transgender, nonbinary, and intersex youth need and deserve an opportunity to play school sports alongside their peers. This is especially the case in contexts that are primarily about the social, educational, and physical benefits of sport, rather than elite competition.  

Therefore, the Department should make clear that restrictions on transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students’ ability to play sports are never permitted at the K-12 or club college level. 

Transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students have been playing sports with their peers for years and with zero problems! In fact, barring trans women and girls from playing with other women and girls harms all women and girls because it can allow anyone to accuse any student athlete of not “really” being a woman or a girl.  Many times, this leads to “sex testing,” which includes horrific and invasive practices like genital inspections or hormonal tests for students to “prove” their gender. 
 
The Department should explicitly state that requiring sex testing of student athletes violates Title IX because such testing causes significant harm to affected students and is never necessary to advance an important educational objective. Sex testing invades students' privacy, is often enforced arbitrarily based on prejudice, and sends deeply stigmatizing and damaging messages to all youth that are completely inconsistent with a supportive educational environment. 
 
Discriminating against and demonizing some students because of who they are or how they look directly violates Title IX. I urge the Department to finalize and strengthen the Department’s Title IX rule to provide strong, clear protections for transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students to participate fully in sports consistent with their gender identity.

Sincerely,
James Long
Hilo, HI 96720

I urge the Department of Education to finalize a Title IX rule that protects the right of students of all ages to participate in sports in every state in the country. Thank you for your consideration

Sincerely,
Sandy Hardwick-Pettis
League City, TX 77573

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
Dear Secretary of Education Miguel Cardona,

The Department of Education (“Department”) is correct in taking action to protect the rights of transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students to play school sports, and I urge the Department to strengthen its Title IX rule to allow transgender, nonbinary, and intersex youth can access the full benefits of an education. Playing school sports as they are is their right. and defending this right is crucial for these students’ well-being and ability to learn without discrimination. 

It is documented that transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students experience high rates of sex discrimination and harassment at school, which is linked to poor academic and health outcomes. Creating affirming policies that allow students to play sports consistent with their gender can reduce stigma, depression, and isolation, and even suicide. 

Transgender, nonbinary, and intersex youth need and deserve an opportunity to play school sports alongside their peers. This is especially the case in contexts that are primarily about the social, educational, and physical benefits of sport, rather than elite competition.  

Therefore, the Department should make clear that restrictions on transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students’ ability to play sports are never permitted at the K-12 or club college level. 

Transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students have been playing sports with their peers for years and with zero problems! In fact, barring trans women and girls from playing with other women and girls harms all women and girls because it can allow anyone to accuse any student athlete of not “really” being a woman or a girl.  Many times, this leads to “sex testing,” which includes horrific and invasive practices like genital inspections or hormonal tests for students to “prove” their gender. 
 
The Department should explicitly state that requiring sex testing of student athletes violates Title IX because such testing causes significant harm to affected students and is never necessary to advance an important educational objective. Sex testing invades students' privacy, is often enforced arbitrarily based on prejudice, and sends deeply stigmatizing and damaging messages to all youth that are completely inconsistent with a supportive educational environment. 
 
Discriminating against and demonizing some students because of who they are or how they look directly violates Title IX. I urge the Department to finalize and strengthen the Department’s Title IX rule to provide strong, clear protections for transgender, nonbinary, and intersex students to participate fully in sports consistent with their gender identity.

Sincerely,
ROBYN WAGONER
Olympia, WA 98502

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
I am writing in opposition to this rule. It puts women on defense, forcing them to justify a right to their own sports and their own spaces.

Allowing males, no matter how they self-identify, into women’s sports erases all pretense of fairness. This rule is blatantly sexist and unfair.

This rule destroys fairness, erases women’s spaces, and eliminates opportunities for women. Protection for women’s sports were created to elevate women to a level playing field, and increase opportunities for scholarships, education, and entrance into the workforce. This rule undoes the work that came before it.

Furthermore, this rule creates a false pretense that women’s physical safety is important to the Department of Education. But any right to safety that must be justified on a case by case basis is not a right. This new rule jeopardizes women by forcing schools to try and win a bureaucratic paperfight to protect women’s sports for women. 

Instead of focusing on their studies, homework, and sports practices, this rule puts the burden on young female athletes to spend their time advocating to their school administration and justifying to the Department of Education that their safety matters.


Do not implement this rule—it will hurt America’s daughters.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
I call on the U.S. Department of Education to stop undermining the protections of Title IX for
female student athletes by coercing schools to allow men and boys to compete in womens and
girls athletics.

Forcing female athletes to compete in their chosen sports against men and boys who identify as
female will destroy a half century of progress under Title IX for women and girls. You will rob
females of spots on teams, push them off podiums to make room for males who have undeniable
biological advantages over female competitors, and deter them from competing in the first place.
This proposed rule will also cause physical harm to female athletes when they have to compete
against larger, stronger men.

The Departments proposed regulation defies Title IX, whose purpose is to provide equal
educational opportunities, including in athletics, based on sex, not gender identity. This
proposed rule denies women and girls an equal playing field in school athletics and sets the
clock back over 50 years, to the time before Congress passed Title IX.

I urge the Department to obey the law and follow common sense by withdrawing its plan to force
women and girls to compete against men and boys in the athletic arena.

The biology between male and female is undeniably inherent and distinct to each sex, giving males, specifically, physical characteristics that make them naturally dominant over females in most sports.

The department’s proposal creates an unfair advantage to males and undermines girls’ and women’s sports.

I urge the Department of Education to recognize the differences and stop placating the movement to destroy the true equality that women have worked so hard to achieve.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
This comment addresses 34 CFR Part 106 [Docket ID ED–2022–OCR–0143] RIN 1870–AA19 Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Sex in Education Programs or Activities Receiving Federal Financial Assistance: Sex-Related Eligibility Criteria for Male and Female Athletic Teams, published on April 13, 2023. 

I am relieved to learn that the Department: (1) is no longer proposing to redefine sex to include “gender identity;” and (2) now seems to acknowledge the material reality of sex.

I strongly oppose redefining sex to include the nebulous and  pseudoscientific category of “gender identity.” All federal efforts to redefine sex to include “gender identity,” including the Department’s July 2022 proposal, depend on the Biden Administration’s repeated mischaracterizations of the Supreme Court’s decision in the matter of Bostock v. Clayton County. 

I have several concerns with the Department’s most recent decision to amend the Title IX regulations. A federal district court has recently ruled that states (and the schools within them) may, consistent with both Title IX and the Equal Protection Clause of the Constitution, maintain single-sex sports. The Department cannot, as a matter of law, prohibit schools from doing something that the Constitution and federal law permit them to do. 

Schools can and should take into account differences in grade and education level, level of competition, and sports for purposes of determining which teams ought to be mixed sex. For example, it might be appropriate for schools to designate teams as mixed sex if there is a small number of girls who want to participate on a particular team but there are not enough such girls to create a female-only team. In such instances, and considering grade level and level of competition, mixed-sex teams might be appropriate. This should not, however, have anything to do with “gender identity.” 

The Department should not be perpetuating the preposterous and extremely dangerous idea that children in elementary school have “gender identities,” even if some teenagers and adults claim to. Stop indoctrinating children with anti-science nonsense. 

The Department is now acknowledging the material reality of sex, which is a start. But it should not assume that “gender identity” is a coherent concept that might, under some circumstances, be permitted to obscure the material reality of sex. The Department should also not expect schools to understand how to navigate all of this even if they want to maintain single-sex sports, which Title IX and the Constitution permit them to do.

Maintaining female-only sports is always substantially related to the achievement of an important educational objective (the inherent purpose of Title IX).

As for “minimizing harms to students whose opportunity to participate on a male or female team consistent with the gender identity would be limited or denied,” I urge the Department to understand that it is always appropriate to minimize harms to students who are confused about their sex (harms that the Department is partially responsible for causing) by helping them to accept themselves as they are – female or male.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
The Biden Administration's proposed policy would allow biological males who identify as female to participate in girls' sports in schools. While this may seem like an act of inclusion, it will negatively impact female athletes who will be forced to compete against biological males who are physically stronger and faster than they are. This creates an unfair playing field for young girls and women alike, and will hinder their ability to compete at a high level. 

Additionally, instituting such policies could put young female students at risk in other ways. For example, allowing male-identifying individuals into girls' locker rooms would create an uncomfortable and potentially dangerous environment for many young women who simply want privacy when changing clothes or showering after physical activity. It's not only unfair but unsafe for them too.

Aside from these safety issues, what's particularly troubling about this situation is how little transparency there has been regarding the specifics of such a policy. The Biden Administration has made vague statements regarding "inclusion" but hasn't clarified what exactly that entails or how it will be enforcedleaving students and institutions in limbo while they wait for further information from the government. To make matters worse, many schools feel pressured into acquiescing since they don't want to be denied federal funding.

The burden shouldnt be on women and schools to prove it.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
The Department of Educations  proposed rule attempts to intimidate school districts into allowing biological males who identify as female to participate in womens sports. This would mean that the male athletes have access to locker rooms and other facilities that were made specifically for female athletes. Not only does this go against the spirit of fairness, but it also puts our daughters at risk of harm and abuse. 


By letting biological males compete with girls in sports, the Biden Administration is erasing any trace of fairness or safety for female athletes. It sets a precedent for young girls that their hard work and dedication are not enough, since they will be competing against someone who has a physiological advantage over them. Furthermore, it puts these young girls in a compromising position by allowing biological males to use the same locker rooms as them. This opens up the possibility of sexual assault and other forms of harassment or abuse from people who do not share the same biological sex. 


This policy directly contradicts the very purpose of Title IX, which was passed in 1972 to promote equal opportunities for men and women in education, including athletics. Allowing biological males to compete with females goes against one of its primary goalsthat men and women should have equal access to sporting activities without discrimination based on sex. If enacted this policy sets a dangerous precedent that will undermine Title IXs original intent and put womens rights at risk. 


The Education Departments  proposed policy is dangerous and wrong on many levels. It undermines fairness by giving male-bodied athletes an advantage over their female-bodied counterparts, compromises safety by allowing male-bodied athletes access to female locker rooms, and violates Title IX by promoting discrimination based on gender identity rather than sex. This policy puts our daughters at risk.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
I am a concerned citizen of Polk County, Florida, and I would like to state a comment concerning Docket ID ED-2022-OCR-0143 (RIN 1870-AA19). In reference to “Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Sex in Education Programs or Activities Receiving
Federal Financial Assistance: Sex-Related Eligibility Criteria for Male and Female Athletic Teams.” Recently, it has come to my attention that a number of organizations have contacted the Polk County School District to pressure school administrators to broaden the language of Title IX to include sexual orientation and gender identity, something which undermines federal law and the legislative authority of the United States Congress. While some progressive organizations have followed the misleading guidance of the Department of Education’s 2021 “Notice of Interpretation” following President Biden’s Executive Order on the Supreme Court ruling in Bostock v. Clayton County, both have been significantly misinterpreted, as it was made clear by the Court that the latter was a Title VII issue that did not apply to Title IX or any other law. The Supreme Court in Bostock emphasized that sex-based employment discrimination
consistent with Title VII was unconstitutional, but explicitly refrained from applying their ruling to Title IX. As such, this renders the Department of Education’s NOI and the Executive Order null because it expressly contradicts Supreme Court precedent.

If this wasn’t enough, there have been a handful of cases further demonstrating the inapplicability of the Bostock ruling to Title IX issues. This includes a recent ruling out of a federal district court issuing a preliminary injunction barring the execution of the Biden Administration’s NOI and Executive Order from taking effect in 20 states including Georgia. Separately, a federal district court in Texas affirmed that “sexual orientation” and “gender identity” are not protected categories because Title IX must be read in the original context in which it was drafted in 1972 in which “sex” under Title IX was understood to be biological and binary. A federal appellate court covering Florida, Georgia, and Alabama jurisdictions also found this to be true, ruling that a local school board’s bathroom policy did not violate Title IX because Title IX conforms to an understanding of “sex” consistent with the societal understanding of sex at the time of its drafting. Beyond this, applying any directive that neither conforms to these recent rulings nor takes into consideration the necessity of receiving congressional approval before making a change to federal law is itself an unconstitutional act. In the Bostock case, the Supreme Court stated that the “people’s representatives” are the ones who must amend Title IX, thereby making it unlawful for unelected officials, including school board members, to assume changes to Title IX in the absence of approval to amend Title IX, a power reserved exclusively by Congress.

I would ask you to consider this information before acting on the coercive tactics by organizations intentionally misapplying Title IX to push a political agenda that would eradicate Title IX’s sex-specific protections that require Title IX to be faithfully understood as it was at the time it was drafted. A serious consequence of this misapplication includes the erosion of student privacy stemming from the rights of students to use sex-separated facilities and to participate in sex-separated sporting activities. To prevent this from happening, I urge you to take my statements into
account as you deliberate further action on this issue. Thank you!

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2023-07601
Comment:
This proposed rule is unfair, raises safety concerns, and tramples on womens rights. 

The Biden Administrations proposed change to Title IX claims to promote equality by allowing students to participate in sports based on their gender identity, not their biological sex. While this may seem like a win for fairness and inclusion, it violates the spirit of fairness that underpins women's athletics. Allowing biological males to compete against biological females puts biologically male athletes at an unfair advantage and could have far-reaching consequences for women's rights in sports. 

This policy will not only violate the spirit of fairness but it could also put female students in danger. By allowing biological males access to female locker rooms, showers, and other facilities, our daughters are at greater risk of sexual assault or harassment. Schools should not be incentivized by federal tax dollars to allow policies that put our children in harm's way. This is unacceptable! 

It is important to note that this policy does not just threaten fairness or put our daughters at risk, it also tramples on womens rights in general. A policy that permits biological males to enter female spaces, sends girls a message that their bodies do not matter as much as those of male-identifying individuals, and that women are second-class citizens. This undermines decades of progress made towards gender equality and equal rights for both sexes.

Protection for women’s sports were created to elevate women to a level playing field, and increase opportunities for scholarships, education, and entrance into the workforce. This rule undoes the work that came before it.

Furthermore, this rule creates a false pretense that women’s physical safety is important to the Department of Education. But any right to safety that must be justified on a case by case basis is not a right. This new rule jeopardizes women by forcing schools to try and win a bureaucratic paperfight to protect women’s sports for women. 

Instead of focusing on their studies, homework, and sports practices, this rule puts the burden on young female athletes to spend their time advocating to their school administration and justifying to the Department of Education that their safety matters.

Let's not role back the advances our women have worked so hard for!  Men, no matter how hard they squeeze their eyes closed and wish, they are not women and will never be able to be, please stop furthering their psychoses.


Do not implement this rule—it will hurt America’s daughters.
